DOC.HEAD: Attempt to Arrest Governor Tied to Coup Attempt Leaves 14 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with some rebels surrendering, 30 hostages released. Pick up 7th graf pvs, ``Troops blocked....' SUBS 2 grafs for final graf to UPDATE with Enrile arraignment delayed.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MLA1,5,6
DOC.TEXT: Officials tried Sunday to arrest a governor indicted in a recent coup attempt, but his supporters defended him in clashes that left at least 14 people dead, including a general, authorities said. The trouble began early Sunday when officials sent to arrest Gov. Rodolfo Aguinaldo in the city of Tuguegarao were taken hostage in a hotel. Later, government forces stormed the hotel, leading to a series of clashes later in the day in the city. At least 10 people were reported wounded. Aguinaldo, a former lieutenant colonel, escaped, but officials said Sunday about 200 of his followers had surrendered. The military chief of staff, Gen. Renato de Villa, placed the armed forces on nationwide alert and ordered the military to capture Aguinaldo ``at all costs.'' Scattered shooting was still reported late Sunday in Tuguegarao, capital of Cagayan province 250 miles north of Manila. Col. Emiliano Templo told reporters Aguinaldo's followers were believed to be holding some people hostage in homes near the hotel. However, Acting Gov. Melvin Vargas said 10 more Aguinaldo followers surrendered early Monday and released about 30 hostages they were holding at a pawn shop. It was unclear if other hostages were still being held. Troops blocked a major bridge south of Tuguegarao, stranding thousands of travelers. Templo said Aguinaldo's followers included his private army, government militiamen and army Scout Rangers. Marines were flown from Manila on Sunday to reinforce security in Tuguegarao, a city of more than 80,000 people. Philippine Airlines canceled flights to the city and schools were ordered closed Monday. In Manila, a homemade bomb exploded late Sunday in the Makati district, but no injuries were reported and it was apparently unrelated to the fighting. Local Governments Secretary Luis Santos and Brig. Gen. Oscar Florendo had gone to Tuguegarao to serve Aguinaldo with the arrest warrant. Before dawn, Aguinaldo's supporters surrounded the six-story Delfino Hotel and took Florendo, chief of the military's civil relations service, and three aides prisoner and trapped Santos and others on the second floor. About 3 p.m., government forces launched an attack. Florendo, 51, was wounded during the rescue and was dead on arrival at a city hospital, said defense spokeswoman Lourdes Ilustre. Santos, two mayors, two colonels and a navy commodore were rescued unharmed, officials said. Casualty figures were incomplete, but regional commander Col. Miguel Fontanilla said at least 14 people died. They included 10 killed during a clash at a checkpoint near a bridge, three in fighting near a gasoline station and Florendo at the hotel, he said. President Corazon Aquino said Florendo ``was killed by one of the followers of suspended Gov. Rodolfo Aguinaldo .... The act of cowardice and treachery of Aguinaldo's followers will not go unpunished. ``I call on all our people to continue to reject violence and uphold our constitutional democracy and the processes of law in a peaceful manner.'' In a radio interview at the hotel earlier Sunday, Aguinaldo said he was a ``victim of injustice .... I don't mind dying as a villain.'' He threatened to take his followers into the mountains and become ``a rebel.'' Aguinaldo was suspended in January as governor of Cagayan province for allegedly supporting the Dec. 1-9 military rebellion and had been holed up in his hometown of Gattaran, 45 miles north of Tuguegarao. Aquinaldo told a Manila radio station on Dec. 1 that he was sending tanks and artillery to the city to support mutineers trying to oust Mrs. Aquino. The governor was indicted along with Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile and five others in connection with the coup attempt, the sixth and bloodiest attempt to topple Mrs. Aquino since she took power in 1986. Enrile appeared in court Monday to face the charge of ``rebellion with murder'' in connection with the failed coup. But the arraignment was put off until the Supreme Court decides whether the charge is valid. The court is to hear arguments Tuesday. Aguinaldo was also implicated but never charged in a August 1987 coup attempt. Later, he raised a private army, ostensibly to fight Communist guerrillas. He ran for provincial governor in January 1988 and was elected by a landslide. Aguinaldo was formerly the provincial commander of Cagayan and many of the troopers assigned there are believed loyal to him.

Star of California College Dies After Collapsing on Court
DOC.TEXT: A college basketball star expected to be chosen in the first round of the professional draft, died Sunday after collapsing during a tournament game. Hank Gathers, 23, crumpled to the court moments after sinking a thunderous slam dunk for Loyola Marymount University in a West Coast Conference tournament game against Portland. He appeared to suffer convulsions for a few seconds while his mother and sister rushed out the stands in front of a hushed crowd at Gersten Pavilion. Their cries were audible to everyone in the building. He was taken to Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Cardiologist Mason Weiss told a news conference the cause of death was unknown and an autopsy would be performed. Gathers was given medication after a similar collapse during a game Dec. 9, and doctors said at the time they believed the problem was an accelerated heartbeat. Gathers was one of only two players in Division I of the National Collegiate Athletic Association to lead the nation in scoring and rebounding in the same season. As a junior last season, Gathers averaged 32.7 points and 13.7 rebounds, joining Xavier McDaniel of Wichita State in 1984-85 as the only NCAA player to lead the nation in both categories. His 1,015 points last season ranked him 11th on the all-time single-season scoring list. A 6-foot-7, 210-pound center from Philadelphia, Gathers was expected to be a first-round selection in this year's National Basketball Association draft. The game was cancelled with Marymount's Lions leading Portland 25-13 in the first half. The rest of the tournament also was postponed. ``It all happened so fast,'' Portland coach Larry Steele said after sending his players back to the team's hotel. ``Within two seconds, everybody realized thatHank needed help. Right now, we're not even having a thought.'' Gathers and teammate Bo Kimble lead the nation in scoring this season.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Overturns Landmark Plastics Ban
DOC.TEXT: A widely imitated environmental law banning plastic food containers and grocery bags was overturned by a state appeals court. The Suffolk County law _ intended to rid dumps of long-lasting plastics _ was invalid because the county failed to prepare an environmental impact statement, the Appellate Division of the state Supreme Court said in a unanimous ruling Friday. The law was hailed by environmentalists and became the model for measures around the country after it was passed in 1988 by the county on Long Island. It banned restaurants, bars, grocery stores and other retail food establishments from using two plastics _ polystyrene, a foam-like material used for cups, trays and cartons, and polyvinyl chloride, used for grocery bags. ``I am going to lift up my plastic-foam cup and salute the judges that struck down a law that would have crippled plastics recycling,'' said Leonard Raskin, a member of the Consumer Packaging Coalition, an industry group that opposed the law. Plastics interests challenged the law because the county hadn't filed an environmental impact statement. Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin said the county ``felt the benefits were obvious and, therefore, didn't require a full impact statement.'' Halpin said the county had yet to decide if it would appeal. But plastics industry officials said it the law would force the use of more paper containers, which also are slow to disintegrate in landfills. ``Switching plastics with paper was nonsense,'' Raskin said. ``Researchers are finding 40-year-old newspapers in California landfills.'' The law's chief sponsor, Legislator Stephen C. Englebright, noted that a state law to protect drinking water requires that all landfills on Long Island close by the end of the year. ``The industry goes in with the specious argument that plastics are better for landfills than paper,'' Englebright said. ``The ruling ignores the fact that we aren't going to have landfills.''

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainian Legislature Votes to Close Chernobyl
DOC.TEXT: The Ukrainian government plans to phase out operations at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant over the next five years, according to reports cited by The Washington Post. However, it is unclear whether the Soviet republic's government has authority over the Chernobyl plant, site of the world's worst nuclear accident. The Post, in its Sunday editions, said an official government publication reported the Ukrainian legislature recently passed a resolution to close the power station. In April 1986, at least 31 people were killed and hundreds more sickened when radiation was released after an explosion and fire at the power plant in the western Soviet republic. Soviet authorities have said they would not close Chernobyl because it would result in an energy shortage in the region and other Warsaw Pact countries in Eastern Europe. However, nuclear power plants in other areas, including Armenia and the Crimea, have been closed because of increased pressure from environmentalists. The Soviet central government has traditionally had authority over facilities such as power plants in local Soviet communities. But recent power-sharing between the republics and Moscow has encouraged speculation that the decision made in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, will stand, the Post said.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Bans Military From Flying Hawaiian Air
DOC.TEXT: Military personnel flying on official duty have been barred from using Hawaiian Airlines, the Department of Defense announced. Discrepancies in the airline's maintenance practices and documentation caused the ruling, Pentagon officials said. The action was taken Feb. 23 following a scheduled week-long maintenance inspection by the Defense Department. ``The company is meeting with the Military Airlift Command and intends to resume MAC charters in the near future,'' Hawaiian Airline spokesman Keoni Wagner said Friday. The carrier has been serving the military since 1963. ``The discrepancies found during the week-long visit concerned maintenance practices, procedures and documentation, which were being done improperly or not at all,'' according to a statement issued through the Air Force Military Airlift Command office at Hickam Air Force Base. The order bars the carrier from serving individual military personnel on commercial flights, or from flying charter flights for military maneuvers.

DOC.HEAD: Bison Hunt Possible After Animals Stray From Park, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: Hunters may be called in to kill some of the 20 bison that wandered out of Yellowstone National Park late last week, state wildlife officials said Saturday. Park bison are thought to carry the disease brucellosis, which can cause spontaneous abortion in cattle. The animals were spotted by a game warden Thursday night grazing outside the park's west boundary, said John Cada of the state Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks. ``A hunt is likely if the bison get in a position where we can take some,'' Cada told The Associated Press. ``We may take a few to encourage the others to return to the park.'' State law allows the controlled hunting of bison that enter Montana from the national park. The policy has aroused the wrath of animal-rights groups, which objected when the state allowed hunters to kill 569 bison last winter.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Reports Iranians in Beirut for Hostage Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: A London newspaper reported Sunday that a delegation of Iranian officials has arrived in Beirut on a mission to free one or more of the Western hostages held in Lebanon. The Independent on Sunday said its information came from unidentified Lebanese and Iranian exiles in London and Paris. ``One exile who took part in previous hostage negotiations said he expected a release within days, but others said a final decision depended on the outcome of political infighting in Tehran,'' the paper said. The report follows a spate of statements from Iranian newspapers and officials in recent days saying the hostages should be released because they are fueling propaganda against Iran. The Independent on Sunday reported the Iranian team sent to Beirut was dispatched by President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran. Iran's so-called pragmatists, led by Rafsanjani, want to repair damaged relations with the West. But they are at odds with hard-line, anti-Western radicals, led by former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi. There are 18 Westerners missing in Lebanon. Most are believed held by pro-Iranian factions. The hostages include eight Americans, four Britons, two Swiss, two West Germans, an Italian and an Irishman. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Newspaperman was Executive Editor of Vicksburg Post
DOC.TEXT: Charles Johnson Faulk Jr., who rose from cub reporter to executive editor of the Vicksburg Evening Post and Vicksburg Sunday Post in a career that spanned a half-century, died Saturday at a hospital. He was 74. Faulk's career with the Vicksburg newspaper began in 1935 when he signed on as a cub reporter. Over the years, he was promoted to city editor, managing editor and executive editor. For the past six years he wrote a Sunday column. Except for a stint in the Navy and 10 years with the state Highway Department in the 1950s and 1960s, Faulk, a Mississippi native, worked for the newspaper until the day his final illness began. When he passed the 50-year mark in the field, he wrote that newspapering, to him, had been ``America at the grassroots. The greatest 50 years of all time, in the greatest profession of all time. I call it life in the fast lane. Life on the wide screen. Three dimensional.'' Faulk was honored many times during his career, including for his role as part of the newspaper's team that received the Pulitzer Prize for coverage of a 1953 tornado. He also covered the founding of local industries, integration, the mechanization of farms and the electrification of the rural South. ``For over 50 years Charlie Faulk was an integral part of the Vicksburg Evening Post,'' said editor and publisher Pat Cashman. ``Charlie was both a gentle person and a gentleman; a person from an age of graciousness and manners that are often lacking today. His loyalty to the newspaper and his work are almost without comparison. ``Charlie was a wordsmith who excelled at his craft. His writing could capture places, events and feelings from long-past days and make them remarkably alive for many people,'' Cashman said. Faulk, a widower, is survived by a brother, a sister, two sons, a daughter, nine grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Funeral services were scheduled for Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Disappearance Threatens Racial Murder Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Hynes maintains ...', with 6 grafs to UPDATE with protest march, ADD that Hynes' predecessor made deal with Vento; pick up 5th graf pvs, ```Without him ...'; SUBS penultimate graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: An important witness went ``into the wind,'' apparently skipping town and carrying with him a key part of the prosecution's case against six white men charged with murdering a black teen-ager. John Vento admitted participating in the Aug. 23 racial attack on Yusuf Hawkins and agreed to testify for the prosecution _ but he disappeared in December. Jury selection in the case was to start Monday. Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said he would seek a one-month adjournment unless the 21-year-old high-school dropout surfaces. On Saturday, meanwhile, about 300 people led by Hawkins' father marched to Vento's home in the mainly white Bensonhurst neighborhood of Brooklyn to protest prosectors' handling of the case. ``It seems that this case has never been taken seriously by the district attorney's office,'' said the Rev. Al Sharpton, a march organizer. Police on motorcycles and wearing riot gear separated the marchers, who arrived in six buses about 2:30 p.m., from Bensonhurst residents. ``Everything was peaceful,'' said Officer Ralph St. Just, a police spokesman. He reported no arrests. Former District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman had struck a deal to drop charges against Vento if he would testify. Hynes, who took office in January, maintains the loss of Vento's testimony would not be devastating. But privately, prosecutors say the case is ``improved immeasurably'' with Vento's participation. ``Without him, is it hopeless? The opinion is divided,'' said one source in the prosecutor's office who spoke on condition that he not be identified. Lawyers for the defendants say even if Vento reappears, Hynes has suffered a major setback. Vento is ``going to be a lowlife with no credibility,'' defense lawyer Stephen Murphy said. Vento was a member of a gang of some 30 young whites _ many of them wielding baseball bats _ who surrounded the 16-year-old Hawkins and three of his friends on a street in the mainly white Bensonhurst neighborhood. The gang had assembled out of a mistaken belief that a group of blacks and Hispanics were about to enter their enclave to attend a neighborhood girl's birthday party and create trouble. Police said the whites set upon Hawkins and his pals, who had come to look at a used car for sale. Joseph Fama, 19, is charged with fatally shooting Hawkins in the chest. Five other whites also have been charged in the killing, and a seventh is charged with assault. Only Fama is being held without bail. Hynes said Vento ``went into the wind'' around Christmas. Authorities do not believe he met with foul play. Instead, Hynes believes Vento ``chickened out'' when faced with the prospect of testifying against his friends. In announcing Vento's disappearance last week, prosecutors tried to lure him back, saying that if he breaks his promise to testify, they have sufficient evidence to charge him with second-degree murder for his role in the attack. Murphy, attorney for alleged Bensonhurst ringleader Keith Mondello, 20, said the credibility of a major witness who prosecutors admit took part in a murder and then fled after cutting a generous deal is nil. The other defense lawyers agree. ``His decision to abscond will probably severely undermine his credibility as a witness,'' said Benjamin Brafman, the lawyer for defendant James Patino, 24. ``I have to assume that prosecutors believe he's going to be a very important witness,'' Brafman said. ``Normally, when a witness who could be a defendant gets a complete pass, that person is deemed extremely important by the prosecution.'' Stanley Meyer, lawyer for the accused triggerman, described Vento as ``an integral part'' of Hynes' case. He said Vento was expected to testify that someone put the gun in Fama's hands. ``We dispute that,'' Meyer said. ``The thought crosses my mind that maybe he doesn't want to testify because he doesn't want to commit perjury.'' Hawkins' parents said Thursday they felt betrayed by prosecutors, who they said promised them there would be no deals with their son's attackers. The case has reunited some of the lead characters from another case that grabbed the city's attention 2{ years ago _ the Howard Beach case, in which a white mob chased a black man onto a highway, where he was killed by a car. Hynes successfully prosecuted that case, and went on to be elected Brooklyn district attorney last year, succeeding Holtzman, who was elected city comptroller. Murphy, a scrappy lawyer who speaks in a scream, defended the only Howard Beach murder defendant who was acquitted.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Protesters Firebomb Peruvian Embassy Sheltering Noriega Officers
DOC.TEXT: Protesters threw firebombs at the Peruvian Embassy on Saturday, angered because the embassy is giving refuge to two officers who were allied with ousted dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. There were no injuries or serious damage in the incident. U.S. soldiers and Panamanian police restored order. The protest was organized by widows of Panamanian soldiers slain in the Oct. 3 attempt to topple Noriega. They are angered that Gonzalo Gonzalez and Heraclides Sucre, who are accused of killing coup leader Maj. Moises Giroldi, have taken refuge in the embassy. Protesters also said they were concerned that the Panamanian government guaranteed safe passage Wednesday to Noriega's family and several other Noriega associates. Noriega's family left into exile Friday night. Giroldi's widow Adela led about 70 protesters, including other widows and relatives of officers executed after surrendering during the insurrection against Noriega, who headed Panama's military until he was overthrown by the United States in a Dec. 20 invasion. The Defense Forces under Noriega had said 10 officers were killed in the coup attempt. A human rights official estimated the total number dead at 77. Mrs. Giroldi said she doesn't know who threw the firebombs. ``It was peaceful and that the incidents were provoked by unknown people,'' she said. ``The pressure that we have been applying is sufficient. It's a matter of being firm with the Peruvian government,'' she added. After the embassy incident, the protesters met with Ricardo Arias Calderon, first vice president and minister of justice and security. Arias Calderon guaranteed the widows that the government would not grant safe conduct to Gonzalez and Sucre. ``I, along with the foreign minister (Julio Linares), are offering our apologies to the government of Peru,'' he said. ``It was a sad incident; it violated international law. There were troublemakers, unknown people.'' No Peruvian diplomats were available for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Striker Killed When Crushed by Bus on Picket Line
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf with police saying fatality appeared accidental; pickup 9th graf, `Initial reports...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY24, RED1, RED2
DOC.TEXT: A striking Greyhound Lines Inc. bus driver was hit by a coach and killed while picketing Saturday in the second day of a walkout that has nearly shut down service by the only nationwide bus company. The striker in Redding, Calif., was crushed against a wall as a temporary driver hired for the walkout was trying to maneuver his bus around a pickup truck driven by another striker, witnesses said. Police questioned the driver but didn't arrest him. Elsewhere, there were scattered confrontations between strikers and replacement drivers in the walkout that stranded many travelers and left hundreds of small communities without public intercity transportation. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, which represents more than 9,000 employees, including all 6,300 drivers and most maintenance and office workers, went on strike Friday after negotiators in Scottsdale, Ariz., failed to reach agreement on pay. No talks were scheduled. Greyhound Chairman Fred G. Currey said Saturday the company was operating 25 percent of its routes and would continue increasing operations each day. He said an additional 700 union-covered employees had crossed picket lines since noon Friday, pushing to 1,800 the number of union members on the job. Of that number, however, only about 350 were drivers. The company also has 700 new hires. Union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson disputed Currey's figures, saying union officials believed just 10 percent of routes were in operation. In the Redding death, police said the replacement driver continued on the route after the bus hit the striker. He later flagged down a Highway Patrol officer and was taken in for questioning, then released without being charged, said police Officer Steve Fiddler. The officer was unable to explain why the driver stopped. ``We don't believe that he intentionally ran over this person,'' police investigator John Severson said. ``Short of that, we're not going to say whether he's wrong or right.'' Initial reports to Greyhound indicated the driver didn't realize he hit the picket, said company spokesman George Gravley in Dallas. Company offials were told the striker was crushed when the bus backed up as the driver tried to maneuver around a pickup truck whose driver was trying to block the way out of the terminal, Gravley said. The victim was Robert Waterhouse, 59, of Redding, 30-year veteran driver planning to retire this year. The replacement driver, Theodore Graham, of Portland, Ore., had worked for two trucking companies and had a safe driving record with both of them, according to his application to Greyhound, Gravley said. Both union officials and Greyhound's Currey issued condolence messages to the dead man's family, but Currey went on to suggest the strikers were at fault. Everyone involved, Currey said, ``will have to live with the circumstances of their behavior, but especially the driver of the pickup.'' The condolence statement by Edward M. Strait, president of the national union, urged strikers and supporters on the picket lines to be ``extremely cautious.'' Currey said the company was seeking several court orders against picket line violence. A Pittsburgh judge issued an order Friday limiting picket lines at the local station to three people. In Chicago, where gunshots were fired at a bus and a terminal the first night of the strike, a judge issued an order Saturday against picket line violence. Two passengers were slightly injured by flying glass. In Philadelphia, three men threw rocks at a bus late Friday, breaking windows and bruising a passenger. Police said the rocks were thrown after the bus, carrying 15 passengers from Washington, stopped about two blocks from Philadelphia's downtown bus terminal because several women jumped in front of it. Two men were arrested. In Toledo, Ohio, a picket was hit by a bus Saturday, but the striker wasn't seriously injured and the driver wasn't charged, police said. During the bus line's last strike, in 1983, a striking Greyhound driver was killed near Zanesville, Ohio, when he was run over while standing in front of a bus being used to train replacement drivers. A grand jury declined to indict. In an Associated Press interview Saturday, Currey said the company had put away enough money to weather a strike. Greyhound is has so many applications for replacement drivers that the company could resume service on all its routes by the end of March if the strike last that long, he said. Currey refused to say how much was set aside as a contingency, but called one reported estimate of $54 million ``conservative.'' Greyhound serves 9,500 destinations, including 9,000 where it is the only intercity transportation available, nd the strike stranded many travelers. The Interstate Commerce Commission, which regulates Greyhound and similar companies, kept regional offices in San Francisco, Chicago and Philadelphia open Saturday to process applications from smaller bus companies that want to serve Greyhound routes. The United Bus Owners of America, representing nearly 1,000 small bus companies, said private operators are prepared to run buses on Greyhound routes around the country. In Chicago, ICC regional officer David Armitage said Saturday morning he had three applications but didn't have specifics. Glenn Eady, ICC regional compliance officer in Philadelphia, said his office had four applications for the Eastern region, which encompasses 23 states from Maine to Florida. In the failed negotiations, the company wanted some pay increases contingent on increased ridership, safety records and productivity factors. The union refuses to accept the contingencies. Greyhound drivers, who according to the company earned an average of $24,743 last year, took a 22 percent pay cut three years ago in negotiations before a leveraged buyout of the company.

DOC.HEAD: Westmar College to Become Branch of Japanese University
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with board votes approval; pick up 9th graf, `Faculty, students ...
DOC.TEXT: Westmar College trustees voted overwhelmingly Saturday to become a branch of Teikyo University of Japan, a merger that Westmar's president called a marriage but four trustees protested by resigning. More than two-thirds of the 37-member board approved the merger after a six-hour session, college President Arthur Richardson said at a news conference late Saturday. He declined to disclose the actual vote count. The agreement will bring a substantial dowry to the tiny, century-old college and gives Tokyo-based Teikyo its third branch in the United States. Teikyo has nine other campuses in Japan, and branches in England and Holland. Robert Rydell of Des Moines, chairman of the board of trustees until he and three other members resigned to protest the merger agreement, said he was ``terribly disappointed'' by the move. ``They have called it a marriage. But in my judgment the engagement period was way too short. We didn't have a chance to get acquainted,'' he said. Richardson said the Board of Trustees would dissolve itself in about 10 days and re-form with at least seven members, the majority of whom will be Americans. The acting chairman of the new board will be Takashi Yamanaka, chairman of the executive committee at Teikyo's Loretto Heights University in Denver. The agreement clears the way for up to 200 Japanese to arrive on the 62-acre campus in April or May and join Westmar's 566 students when classes begin in September, Richardson said. He said up to 200 more would arrive in Le Mars, about 20 miles northeast of Sioux City, for the fall term in 1991. Teikyo has an enrollment of more than 13,000 students. It already has agreements to buy Loretto Heights from Regis College and to buy Salem College in Salem, W. Va. ``Iowa is `down to earth' and its people have very healthy minds. I'd like to introduce that to Japanese. It's important to introduce your Iowa values,'' Yamanaka said earlier. Faculty, students and trustees were disappointed Richardson didn't tell them what was going on until last month. The merger talks began in November. ``It did kind of happen all of a sudden,'' Richardson said. ``But you can't announce a gift you don't have.'' On the edge of financial collapse in the mid-1980s when enrollment bottomed out at 417 students, Westmar has been searching for ``some kind of international arrangement,'' he said. Others worried that the United Methodist Church would sever its relationship with Westmar. The college, celebrating its centennial this year, receives about $90,000 annually from the church. Gregory Clapper, a Methodist minister and the school's director of religion and philosophy programs, said the school's mission is more important than money. ``What has always been more important for many people than the money which the institution gives to Westmar is the simple, powerful, symbolic statement: `We are a United Methodist College,''' Clapper wrote in a letter published in the Le Mars Daily Sentinel. Le Mars Chamber of Commerce President John Boyd, a 1967 graduate of Westmar, said the Japanese students would help the local economy. ``For every $1 spent, that would be turned over seven times. If a student from Westmar comes in and spends $100 a month, they're infusing $700 into our economy,'' Boyd said. Other residents want the Japanese to stay away. ``Our leaders in Washington have been giving in to Japan. Our ex-president even went over and got paid off after he got out of office. Also, why should we pay for all the military protection for Japan and then let Japan come over here and buy us out?'' Don Eickholt of Hinton said in a letter to the Sentinel, referring to a recent trip by former President Reagan paid for by a Japanese company. ``I believe they want students schooled in this country so they will be able to take over,'' his letter said. ``The younger generation think dealing with Japan is a way to make a buck, and that is important to them. Who won World War II, I wonder.''

DOC.HEAD: Slavic Republics Head to Polls in Local Balloting
DOC.TEXT: Millions of Soviets voted throughout the country's Slavic heartland on Sunday in a test of the Communist Party and government apparatus' power to withstand rising demands for democracy. Nearly 150 million voters living from the Polish border to the Bering Strait were to choose candidates for 1,800 seats in the legislatures of the Russian, Ukrainian and Byelorussian republics. Thousands of seats in local governing councils also were being contested. The balloting came in a period of increasing political tension as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms reached a critical stage. Gorbachev has pressed the Communist Party into giving up its constitutional monopoly on power, and the national Congress of People's Deputies meets in a week to debate creating a new and more powerful presidency. Pro-democracy rallies in Moscow and across the country have drawn hundreds of thousands of people. But hundreds of longtime party and government officials were on the ballots and official newspapers were full of stories of campaign tricks and porkbarrel politics as they sought to avoid the kind of embarrassing defeats they suffered last year in balloting for the national Congress. Balloting in the dominant Slavic republics followed votes in the Baltic republic Lithuania swept by candidates endorsed by the pro-independence Sajudis movement, and several other republics.

DOC.HEAD: Precede: LUSAKA
ANC Leader Arrives to Emotional Welcome in Zimbabwe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Mandela arriving in Zimbabwe
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela arrived Sunday in Zimbabwe on the second stop of the South African black leader's four-nation tour. Mandela, 71, vice president of the African National Congress, was emotionally welcomed at Harare airport by the former guerrilla chieftain who became Zimbabwe's first black ruler in what once was a British colony. President Robert Mugabe, who long agitated for Mandela's release from South African prisons, embraced the ANC activist on the tarmac as thousands of wellwishers cheered to the throb of tribal drummers when Mandela arrived from Zambia. ``You're not a stranger,'' Mugabe declared as school children in feather head-dresses chanted, ``We're Going to Pretoria to fight.'' ``You've come home where the 10 million people stand solidly behind the people of South Africa in the unrelenting struggle,'' he added. Larger-than-life portraits of Mandela festooned lamp posts and trees on the road to the airport. Mandela, freed on February 11 after 27 years' imprisonment for anti-government activities, will witness first-hand how white-governed Rhodesia was transformed into black-ruled Zimbabwe. Aides to the ANC leader say he views Zimbabwe as a possible model for a future South Africa. Mugabe himself spent 10 years in detention under the regime of Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian D. Smith before he led the seven-year war that yielded independence in 1980. Since then, Mugabe has pursued a policy of reconciliation between whites and blacks, rival tribes and opposing political movements. Whites have held Cabinet posts. Mandela was to address a rally called by Mugabe to launch his ruling Zimbabwe African National Union (Patriotic Front) party's campaign for parliamentary and presidential elections at the end of this month. Later, Mandela will be feted at a government banquet and on Monday he will visit Heroes' Acre _ a North Korean-built monument to the 27,000 Zimbabweans killed in the independence war. After spending three days in Zimbabwe, the ANC leader is scheduled to visit ANC facilities, including guerrilla training camps, in Tanzania. He is expected to visit Tambo in Sweden before ending his first foreign trip since he made a clandestine border crossing in 1962 to undergo political training Ethiopia.

DOC.HEAD: Military Takes Over in South African Black Homeland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE that coup occurred early Sunday, scene, Gqozo reportedly coup leader, background. Pickup 7th graf `Ciskei, a...'
DOC.TEXT: The military in the nominally independent Ciskei homeland overthrew the government early Sunday, detained top army officials and placed the Cabinet under house arrest, an officer announced over local radio. Brig. O.J. Gqozo said on Radio Ciskei that the army seized the government of President Lennox Sebe in a bloodless coup after repeated pleas from the public. More than two hours before the broadcast, South African Foreign Minister Pik Botha had announced in Pretoria that there had been an attempted coup overnight in Ciskei, and that all parties had been asked to remain calm. He said he would try to reach Sebe, who the South African Press Association said was on a trade mission to the Far East. Sebe was president of the Republic of Ciskei on South Africa's southern coast since it was declared independent in 1981. The presidential palace was deserted, with the doors standing open, but the capital, Bisho, was calm, reported Louise Flanagan, a journalist from the independent Albany News Agency. Gqozo said Lt. Gen. Kwame Sebe, son of the overthrown president, had been detained, along with the commander of the defense force, Brig. S.S. Zwelendaba, and the second in command, Brig. A. Sixishe. The radio announcement said Cabinet ministers had been placed under house arrest. Gqozo was the leader of the coup and had been recalled early this year from Pretoria, where he had been Ciskei's military attache to South Africa, a Ciskei Radio journalist told the South African Press Association. The journalist, who was not identified, said the coup had been led by soldiers at the Jongunso Bomvu military headquarters in King William's Town, where Gqozo was based. Ciskei, a 3,600-square-mile homeland of the Xhosa tribe, is not recogized outside South Africa. South Africa has 10 tribal homelands, designated by the white minority government as the countries of origin of the black majority of 28 million. The homelands comprise most of the 13 percent of South African territory where blacks are allowed to own land. Anti-apartheid organizations such as the African National Congress oppose the homelands system, saying it deprived black South Africans of their citizenship rights and separate whites and blacks.

DOC.HEAD: Army Ends Hostage Standoff With Renegade Governor; 14 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with 14 killed, 200 followers arrested, edits to tighten. Pickup 17th graf, `He was...'
DOC.TEXT: Government troops in a northern city Sunday attacked a hotel seized by supporters of a governor who was indicted in a coup attempt. At least 14 people, including a general, were killed, officials said. At least 10 others were wounded in a series of clashes in Tuguegarao between government forces and followers of suspended Gov. Rodolfo Aguinaldo, who escaped during the fighting. His whereabouts were unknown. Aguinaldo, a former lieutenant colonel, was indicted for rebellion and murder in the Dec. 1-9 failed coup seeking to overthrow President Corazon Aquino. Military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa placed the armed forces on nationwide alert and ordered the capture of Aguinaldo ``at all costs.'' Many of Aguinaldo's followers were members of a militia raised, trained and equipped by the Aquino administration. About 200 of them surrendered. One of the victims, Brig. Gen. Oscar Florendo, had gone to Tuguegarao, 250 miles north of Manila, to serve Aguinaldo with the arrest warrant, said local Governments Secretary Luis Santos. Before dawn, Aguinaldo's supporters surrounded the six-story Delfin Hotel and took Florendo, chief of the military's civil relations service, and three aides prisoner and trapped Santos and others on the second floor. About 3 p.m., government forces launched an attack. Florendo, 51, was wounded during the rescue and was dead on arrival at a city hospital, said defense spokeswoman Lourdes Ilustre. Santos, two mayors, two colonels and a navy commodore were rescued unharmed, officials said. Santos said, ``This rebellion is open defiance of the established authority and they must be brought to the bar of justice.'' Casualty figures were incomplete, but regional commander Col. Miguel Fontanilla said at least 14 people died. They included 10 killed during a clash at a checkpoint near a bridge, three in fighting near a gasoline station and Florendo at the hotel. Mrs. Aquino said Florendo ``was killed by one of the followers of suspended Gov. Rodolfo Aguinaldo. ... The act of cowardice and treachery of Aguinaldo's followers will not go unpunished. ``I call on all our people to continue to reject violence and uphold our constitutional democracy and the processes of law in a peaceful manner,'' she said. In a radio interview at the hotel earlier Sunday, Aguinaldo said he was a ``victim of injustice. ... I don't mind dying as a villain.'' He threatened to take his followers into the mountains and become ``a rebel.'' Aguinaldo had been holed up in his hometown of Gattaran, about 45 miles north of Tuguegarao. He was suspended in January as governor of Cagayan province for allegedly supporting the military rebellion. He told a Manila radio station on Dec. 1 that he was sending tanks and artillery to the city to support mutineers trying to oust Mrs. Aquino. The governor was indicted along with Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile and five others in connection with the sixth and bloodiest attempt to topple Mrs. Aquino since she took power in the February 1986 uprising against the late President Ferdinand Marcos. Cagayan is Enrile's home province and his political stronghold. Aguinaldo, a former lieutenant colonel, was implicated but never charged in the August 1987 coup attempt. Later, he resigned his commission and raised a private army, ostensibly to fight Communist guerrillas. He ran for provincial governor in January 1988 and was elected by a landslide. Aguinaldo was formerly the provincial commander of Cagayan and many of the enlisted troopers assigned there are believed loyal to him.

DOC.HEAD: A Bishop with a Convert's Zeal _ for Reform
DOC.TEXT: The only bishop to have signed a recent statement calling for drastic reforms in the Roman Catholic Church says he's prepared to live with the reverberations. ``Christ didn't promise us an easy life,'' Bishop Emerson Moore said. ``What we need is honesty and openness in the church _ true dialogue,'' he said in an interview. ``If that means I have to suffer for saying so, that's all right.'' But so far, he said, ``I haven't been called a heretic. My loyalty to the Holy Father (Pope John Paul II) and His Eminence (Cardinal John O'Connor) is certainly not in question.'' The ``Call for Reform,'' published Wednesday as an advertisement in The New York Times, urged basic changes in the church, including the ordination of women and married men as priests. Moore is one of seven auxiliary bishops who serves the archdiocese of New York under Cardinal O'Connor, the most prominent conservative among American prelates. O'Connor said last week he did not believe ``the statement advances the spirit of the (Second Vatican) Council.'' He also complained that several of its proposals ``implicitly reject positions clearly affirmed by successive popes, including Pope John Paul II, and can but lead to confusion about Church teaching.'' In theology, causing confusion is a serious charge, and Moore said O'Connor had told him how he felt about the statement. But Moore said he does not fear retribution. ``There may be differences of opinion among us, but the archdiocese has always been a family to me, and supportive of me,'' he said. ``There's leeway to disagree, thank God.'' Moore, one of 13 black American bishops, was arrested in 1984 for blocking the entrance to the South African consulate in New York. Moore said O'Connor supported his stand ``even though the cardinal would not have done that himself.'' The statement Moore signed was drawn up by several liberal Catholic groups. Moore said he was particularly impressed with its complaint that groups are ``marginalized in our church because of race and ethnic identity.'' The statement also says the church ``is crippled by its failure to address fundamental justice issues within its structures'' and is ``a stumbling block to both its own members and to society.'' The statement's signers said they see ``theologians silenced, constructive opposition condemned, loyalty oaths imposed and blind obedience demanded'' and ``church officials conducting financial dealings in secret without accountability to the people.'' The statement asks the pope to share his power. It asserts the right of priests, nuns and lay Catholics to help select their local bishops and to be consulted in the development of church policy on sexual issues. The call for reform was initiated by Chicago-based Call to Action, a group that hopes to collect 100,000 signatures by year's end. So far the statement has been signed by about 4,500 Catholics, including a number of prominent theologians and numerous nuns and priests. And one bishop. Moore said he received the statement in the mail several months ago and decided to sign because ``I was interested in its basic thrust, even though I didn't agree with every statement.'' One change of which he is particularly leery, he said, is the ordination of women. Margaret McClory of Call to Action said Moore was sent the statement because he was on the group's mailing list, and that individual bishops were not asked to sign. Moore, 61, converted to Catholicism when he was 15 and became a bishop at the relatively young age of 44. He supported the presidential candidacy of Jesse Jackson, although the church frowns on such political involvement by its clergy, and repeatedly has asserted that the church has racist tendencies. But when George Stallings, a black priest in Washington, broke away from the church last year and held his own services, Moore joined the other black bishops in renouncing his move. McClory said several Catholics who helped pay for the ad asked that their names be withheld because they worked for church institutions. Moore said he did not think his own career in the church had been harmed. Then he added: ``I'd much rather spend the rest of my life in New York anyway.''

DOC.HEAD: Club Med Founder Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Gerard Blitz, founder of the Club Mediterranee empire of vacation villages billed as an ``antidote to civilization,'' has died in a Paris hospital, company officials said Sunday. He was 78. Blitz died Saturday night at Cochin Hospital following a serious illness, the officials said. The cause of death was not disclosed. A Belgian-born diamond-cutter by trade, Blitz created Club Med in 1950 as a nonprofit association and led the first group of vacationers to a tent village in Spain's Balearic Islands. Club Med villages progressed from tents to straw huts to modern hotel facilities, prospering with a formula of completely pre-paid, no-tipping vacations in which clients pay with colored beads for the few extras like souvenirs or bar drinks. With its image of sun, sand and relaxation, Club Med grew into one of the world's largest tourism groups, with more than 87,000 beds in its resorts. Much of the credit for the growth went to Gilbert Trigano, who supplied tents for Club Med in the early years, joined the company in 1954 and succeeded Blitz as president in 1963. Blitz remained honorary president until his death and continued to participate in the company's planning sessions. ``He was an extraordinary man who had an immense understanding of life,'' Trigano said Sunday. ``He was a man of happiness.'' Blitz, who was born Feb. 28, 1912, was married twice, first to Denise Libbrecht and then to Claudine Coindeau. He had four sons and a daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Two Passenger Trains Collide; Two Killed, 60 Injured
DOC.TEXT: Two passenger trains collided head-on Sunday, killing at least two people and injuring 60, the Anatolia news agency said. Causes of the crash in Polatli, 45 miles southwest of Ankara, were not immediately clear. A train from Ankara heading for Istanbul rammed into an Ankara-bound train from the Aegean coastal city of Izmir, the news agency said. Thirty-three of the injured passengers were hospitalized, four in serious condition, said Anatolia. The engineer of the Ankara-bound train died and rescue workers later pulled the body of a passenger from a derailed car, the agency said. Anatolia quoted the engineer of the Istanbul-bound train as saying he stepped on the brakes then jumped from the train just before impact. A passenger fom Izmir, Bulent Isiten, said his train had just stopped at the Polatli station and was gaining speed before the collision. ``I think the other train was coming at a very high speed,'' Isiten told Anatolia. Signal failure or error by one of the engineers may have caused the crash, said Birkan Erdal, director of Turkey's railway authority.

DOC.HEAD: Ninety-Five Guerrillas Captured in Security Operation
DOC.TEXT: Army and police units working together captured 95 leftist guerrillas in the northern Andes, officials said. Elsewhere Saturday, rebels shot and killed an employee of a government irrigation project at his home in Ayacucho, 230 miles southeast of Lima, police said. And in Huancayo, 140 miles east of Lima, rebels shot and killed two men and a woman in separate incidents. Police said rebels left a note on one victim reading, ``This is how thieves die.'' The 95 Shining Path rebels were captured in Yanama, 215 miles northeast of Lima in the Black Mountains, an interior department spokesman said. Arms and explosives were also recovered, he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Shining Path has been fighting Peru's elected governments since 1980. The government says more than 18,000 people have been killed in the fighting, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: House Collapses, Kills Seven
DOC.TEXT: A mud house collapsed during heavy rains, killing seven members of a family near the southern coastal town of Cox's Bazaar, police said Sunday. Three other people were injured in the collapse, which occured Saturday on the outskirts of the town, 185 miles southeast of Dhaka, police said on condition of anonymity. Two days of heavy rains disrupted life in Cox's Bazaar, located on the Bay of Bengal. The victims included an 11-day-old infant and its mother, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives 19 Points Behind; Poll Indicates By-Election Loss
DOC.TEXT: The Conservatives lagged 19 percent behind the opposition Labor Party in a poll published Sunday, the governing party's worst showing in 20 years. Another poll showed the Conservatives in danger of losing a formerly safe seat in Parliament in a by-election later this month in central England. A poll published in The Sunday Correspondent showed 52 percent favored Labor, the first time the survey showed the opposition party with a majority. That was a 4 percent gain for Labor since January, while the Conservatives dropped four points to garner 33 percent support. For the poll, 1,439 adults were interviewed on February 23 and 24. A Gallup poll published Friday put the Conservatives 18.5 points behind the Labor Party _ a 20-year low in the Gallup survey. A poll for The Sunday Times in mid-Staffordshire, where voters will chose a member of Parliament on March 22, showed Labor leading the Conservatives by 50 percent to 36 percent. That poll was based on interviews with 862 adults between February 28 and March 2. No margin of error was given for any of the polls.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Still Hedging on Border Issue
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany is embroiled in controversy over his refusal to categorically accept the Polish-German border set at the end of World War II. It has become a political issue; recognition of the boundary could cost Kohl votes in the December West German election. But his failure to renounce any future attempt to regain former territories lost in the war could delay German reunification. Kohl has come under attack from Poland, from the World War II Allies and from the opposition in West Germany and even in his own Cabinet for failing to give an unequivocal promise on the border. There have been demonstrations in Poland in support of Polish demands to take part in talks on reunification. But the chancellor faces considerable political risk if he declares the current border inviolable. Kohl's Christian Democratic Union is running only a couple of percentage points ahead of the opposition Social Democrats in public opinion polls. The CDU traditionally has enjoyed the backing of conservative West Germans, including millions of exiles from territories now governed by Poland and the Soviet Union. More than 12 million ethnic Germans were driven from Silesia and East Prussia after the Third Reich was vanquished. The lands east of the Oder and Neisse rivers that were German before the war are now Polish territory, comprising about one-third of modern day Poland. If Kohl agrees to give up the lands, he could alienate those voters who provide his party's narrow lead over the Social Democrats. However, Kohl's equivocating has cost the CDU support in East Germany, where the Social Democrats are expected to win a majority in March 18 elections. West German political parties have been active in the East German campaign in an attempt to increase their voter base in anticipation of unification. Kohl has to be worried that the addition of a solidly Social Democratic East German electorate could tip the political balance and deprive him of his dream of being the first chancellor of a reunited Germany. Recognition of the current German-Polish boundary is likely to be one of the prices of unification demanded by the World War II Allies, who will have a say in the shape of a united Germany. Under pressure from Washington, where President Bush urged clarity on the border issue, Kohl last week expressed understanding for Poland's concern. His government also offered to respect the border between Poland and a unified Germany if Poland drops any claims to war reparations and promises to protect the rights of its German minority. But he has stopped short of saying Germany would never seek recovery of those lands, saying only a united Germany could officially recognize its borders in a peace treaty. ``In many speeches I have said that no one wants to connect the unity of the Germans with moving the borders. I don't know what more I can say,'' Kohl told East German television on Wednesday. He urged a declaration be made by both German parliaments to respect the postwar boundaries, but exile groups claim Kohl still supported them. ``The chancellor has not qualitatively changed his position on this issue,'' said Horst-Egon Rehnert, spokesman for the 2-million-member Association of Exiles in Bonn. ``We have absolutely no problem with this statement.'' The conservatives' view that nothing has been given up has left moderates and liberals concerned that Kohl still sees the border question as open. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, whose Free Democrats are aligned with Kohl in the Bonn government, has promised that ``unification will not be accompanied by any territorial demands.'' The chancellor's refusal to give in on the issue has won back some of the arch-conservative vote that strayed to the ultra-rightist Republicans party last year. The Republicans, led by former Waffen SS soldier Franz Schoenhuber, polled as much as 10 percent in regional elections last year, but have recently fallen to less than 4 percent support nationally. Schoenhuber has increased pressure on Kohl by demanding eventual unification with Silesia and East Prussia, offering a political haven for exiles and others who still seek recovery of the lost territories. Association of Exiles director Hartmut Koschyk warned that if West Germany renounces claims to the former German lands, those driven out four decades ago will seek compensation of $59 billion from the Bonn government for land, homes and other assets left behind. Koschyk also predicted that as many as 500,000 ethnic Germans now living inside Poland would emigrate to West Germany if their hopes of unification were permanently dashed.

DOC.HEAD: National Transportation Policy To Focus on Local Government, Private Help
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will unveil a national transportation policy this week calling for more local government and private help to improve air, ground and water transportation into the next century. The long-awaited outline could lead to more toll roads, higher airline ticket fares, increased gasoline taxes in some areas and higher bus and mass transit fares. Major elements of the policy already have been disclosed by Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner, who says he wants to ``remove the heavy hand of government'' from transportation industries. Formal release is set for Thursday. Skinner's department faces formidable problems: overcrowded airports with about 30 percent of all flights delayed; a maritime industry in a record slump; highway bridges in need of billions of dollars in repairs; and an estimated $1 trillion to $3 trillion demand for airport, railroad, highway and mass transit construction over the next 20 years. Skinner's solutions focus on increasing the nation's reliance for transport on the private sector and state and local governments by ``stimulating competition and allowing the magic of the marketplace to work.'' But Skinner has said the policy also will commit the federal government to ``fully using the funds that people have paid in user charges for transportation, for investments in transportation.'' The unspent $7.6 billion in the aviation trust fund, collected from an airline ticket tax, and the $10.1 billion in the highway trust fund, have been a sore point with transportation industry officials who say the money is going to offset the federal deficit rather than to help transportation. Some of the strategies Skinner has said will be promoted in the new policy are increased user fees, which he does not call tax hikes; increased private investment, including private construction of toll roads; extending deregulation to the trucking and maritime industries; and promotion of new technologies, including high-speed rail systems and ``smart cars'' that are less likely to crash. Major points Skinner has disclosed so far from the policy include: _ Promotion of a ``stronger, healthier partnership among federal, state and local governments,'' with ``regulatory flexibility,'' which Skinner has said could include new powers to levy local highway tolls. _ A concentration of federal assistance on ``projects of national significance,'' although the projects will not be identified in the policy document. _ Preservation of existing transportation systems, including the interstate highway system. _ A focus on ``moving people and goods _ not just vehicles,'' with promotion of high-occupancy vehicle lanes for crowded commuter routes. _ Encouragement of technology and innovation in all modes of transportation. Even before it has been released, the policy has attracted criticism, although Skinner is widely praised for undertaking the task. ``Flexibility sounds like a euphemism for `take care of yourself,''' Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., told Skinner as the secretary unveiled a portion of his plan before a Senate appropriations subcommittee last week. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato of New York, ranking Republican on the same subcommittee, said he feared the new policy would not help the continued development of large mass transit systems that take cars off the roads and decrease pollution. Carole Perkins, spokeswoman for the Association of American Railroads, said the rail industry supports Skinner's efforts and appreciates his commitment to treat all industries evenly and get rid of unneeded regulations. But she said railroad officials are looking for specifics and that it appears the policy will deal mostly in generalities. Airline industry officials have said they would like to see a separate policy outline from the Federal Aviation Administration, since Skinner's plan will give equal importance to all means of moving goods and people around the country. One problem airline officials say the policy is unlikely to address is the need for unified noise standards at airports. The new transportation policy is contained in a document that has passed the scrutiny of the White House's fiscal office, the Office of Management and Budget. Skinner told a congressional committee last week that reports that OMB would impose significant changes in the policy were not true. He described White House changes as ``wordsmithing'' only. The policy is the result of 117 ``town meeting''-style hearings held in 48 cities over the past year. Parts of it already are being implemented, according to Transportation Department officials, and some of its proposals are contained in Bush's fiscal 1991 budget, including calls for airport passenger fees and other increases in revenue from transportation users.

DOC.HEAD: Military Leaders Say America Faces Era of `Violent Peace'
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is wasting no time offering answers to one of the most compelling questions raised by the demise of the Cold War: Who is the enemy now? It's drug runners, terrorists, Third World despots and even oil spills, the Pentagon brass say. At the same time, they haven't dismissed entirely the threat of Soviet attack on the West, even as Moscow begins pulling its troops out of Eastern Europe. The world has entered an ``era of violent peace,'' says Adm. Carlisle Trost, the Navy's top officer. It is a time of reduced odds that the superpowers will lob nuclear missiles at each others' cities, but of more frequent and more lethal conflict among rival Third World nations, he told Congress recently. The message from the Pentagon is that not only is the military needed for its traditional mission, but that military might must be tailored to battle exotic new threats, ones not previously considered big risks to the future of Western democracy. It's unclear how this notion will sell on Capitol Hill. Lawmakers are looking for ways to carve a ``peace dividend'' out of next year's defense budget. Many see the outbreak of peace as a chance to rein in the $300 billion-a-year military. Some private analysts say the Pentagon legitimately is concerned by a proliferation of modern arms, including chemical weapons, in the Third World. But they say military leaders also may be overstating the immediacy of these dangers. A civil war in a Third World country, for example, may pose less danger to U.S. security now than a few years ago, when Moscow may have been more likely to exploit such openings for the advancement of communism, said Alexis Cain, an analyst at the Defense Budget Project, a non-partisan research group in Washington. Even so, instability in the Third World is emerging as one of the U.S. military's main arguments against stripping it of manpower and modernized weaponry. ``The Pentagon is more desperate for missions now'' that the world order has shifted, Cain said. The military leaders, however, insist it's too soon to relax on any front. ``Perhaps we are at the end of the Cold War. However, this does not mean the end of ... military rivalry among nations,'' Trost said. ``It may well mean increased instability ... and violence.'' A similar view was advanced by Donald Rice, the Air Force secretary: ``The likelihood that the U.S. military will be called upon at some time and place to defend U.S. interests in a lethal environment is high _ but now, more than ever, the time and place are difficult to predict.'' Thus the U.S. military must be prepared to act as a force for stability in every corner of the globe, the Pentagon chiefs say. But many in Congress say it's not yet clear just what needs stabilizing, or if America is best suited for such a role. Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee and a strong supporter of the military, told Army Secretary Michael Stone at a hearing Feb. 27 that he'd better find a more explicit mission than ``stability.'' ``What do you put on a recruiting poster now _ `Join the Army and become a stability force'''? Warner said. Each service's civilian and uniformed chiefs have testified before Congress in recent weeks on President Bush's plan for a slight cut in next year's defense budget. And each has ticked off the same list of security threats said to be replacing the traditional worry about a Soviet attack on Western Europe or America: _Third World countries with increasingly sophisticated weaponry. Gen. Carl Vuono, the Army chief of staff, cited Libya as an example. He said it has more battle tanks than either France or Britain. Several other countries, including Syria, India and Iraq, each have more battle tanks than France and Britain combined, Vuono said. _Drug traffickers. Stone told Congress on Feb. 21 that the drug trade has created ``an unprecedented and perplexing threat to our national security.'' Compounding the problem, he said, is evidence that terrorist groups are becoming more involved in narcotics trafficking as a revenue source and a network for buying arms. _Terrorism. Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, acknowledged to Congress that military force is ``only infrequently'' the right answer to terrorism, but Stone said terrorism was a ``primary threat'' to American citizens. The military says it also can make itself useful at home, helping civilian authorities respond to disasters such as last year's Exxon oil spill in Alaska.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Approaches `Red October' Author to Run For Congress
DOC.TEXT: National Republican leaders have urged best-selling author Tom Clancy to run for Congress, but he says he is too busy promoting the movie adapted from his book, ``The Hunt For Red October.'' ``It certainly deserves consideration, civic duty and all that,'' said Clancy. But he's busy with interviews and promotional appearances for the film starring Sean Connery that premiered Friday, and said he has ``not had any time to consider'' a race against incumbent Rep. Roy P. Dyson, D-Md. Clancy, 42, a Republican who lives in southern Maryland's Calvert County, was asked to challenge the five-term Democrat during a GOP conference two weeks ago in Princeton, N.J. Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., announced at a dinner attended by Clancy that Republicans were urging him to enter the race. Clancy also was approached by Ed Rollins, chief tactician for the National Republican Congressional Committee, and other Republicans, The (Baltimore) Sun reported. ``Obviously we'd love to see him run,'' said NRCC spokesman John Roberts. ``He's articulate and popular.'' Clancy, whose novels such as ``Red Storm Rising'' and the most recent ``Clear and Present Danger'' focus on superpower rivalry and sophisticated weapons systems, was in Princeton for a panel discussion on strategic weapons. Maryland Republicans sound less enthusiastic about a Clancy candidacy. ``We have seven very good candidates for the 1st Congressional District,'' said Maryland GOP Chairman Joyce Lyons Terhes. ``I feel that one of them will be the next congressman from the 1st District.'' Rep. Helen Delich Bentley, a Republican from Maryland's 2nd District, noted that some of the Republican challengers in the 1st District have been working for more than a year. Maryland constituents want a congressman ``available to them all the time,'' she said. ``Is Tom Clancy ready to make that commitment?''

DOC.HEAD: `Cultural Landmark' Status Sought for Famous Tavern
DOC.TEXT: The spirit of the Blue Moon is evident before you enter the tavern, a hangout for artists, poets, writers and other specimens of high life and low life for more than half a century. The atmosphere is special _ Northwest bohemian _ but is it enough to designate the tavern a cultural landmark and save it from the wrecking ball? That's the question facing the Landmarks Preservation Board on Wednesday. The owner of the dingy brick tavern wants to tear it down along with a strip joint and a house to make way for a residential and retail complex. ``It's a unique tavern and it's a fun tavern, but it's not a historic landmark,'' said Robert Hannah, president of Westlake Capital Corp., which bought the building last September. ``All this stuff about cultural landmark, I think, is stretching the truth.'' Supporters and the owners of the tavern concede it is architecturally insignificant. They focus on its past patronage. Blue Moon historians count writers Jack Kerouac and and Dylan Thomas among its former customers. David Wagoner is said to have written poetry in a back booth; Allen Ginsberg, abstract graffiti in the restroom; and Jack Leahy, the outlines for short stories on a wobbly table. In January, the Landmarks Preservation Board nominated the Blue Moon, but late last month the agency's staff recommended that landmark status be denied. The staff report agreed with Hannah, who said the tavern failed to meet structural requirements, mostly because of remodeling in the last 25 years. Landmark status would prevent the owners from tearing down the tavern, and any remodeling would be subject to restrictions. The building housing Blue Moon was built as a garage in 1923 and converted into one of the city's first post-Prohibition taverns 11 years later. Its location was close to the boundary of an area around the University of Washington where sales of alcoholic beverages were banned. Inside, the clacking billiard balls, raucous laughter, animated conversation and gurgling taps drown out the bump-and-grind sounds from Fan Tan Follies, a strip joint next door. It's a scene of scruffy sociability among working stiffs, bar stool leftists, lawyers, professors and students. In a New Republic magazine article after her first visit, Carolyn Kizer described the Blue Moon as ``a grubby oasis just outside the university's one-mile Sahara. Here, the jukebox roars, Audrey the waitress slaps down schooners of beer, and poets, pedants, painters and other assorted wildlife make overtures to each other.'' Hannah said it would be too costly to build around the existing tavern, but he'd like to incorporate the Blue Moon in the $3 million project. Blue Moon backers said that would be impossible. ``We would look at it only as a last-ditch resort,'' said Walt Crowley, a television commentator, political activist and former mayoral aide who helped organize the 1,500-member Forever Blue Moon Committee. He bemoaned the fate of other gritty taverns reopened in newer quarters. ``They had their tummies tucked and their tushes taken up to the point that they became virtually unrecognizable,'' Crowley said. ``Their integrity has been essentially destroyed.'' Blue Moon supporters include University of West Florida sociology professor Ray Oldenburg, author of ``The Great Good Place.'' He wrote that in the last 40 years, the number of taverns in the United States has dropped from 152,000 to fewer than 50,000. ``What we're really talking about is an endangered species here,'' Oldenburg said in a telephone interview. ``There is a cultural tradition here ... an interesting, rather dingy, but worth keeping kind of place.''

DOC.HEAD: Mine Explodes as Soldiers Search Border Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: A mine exploded Sunday while soldiers were exploring a tunnel allegedly dug under the border by North Korea, killing a sentry dog but causing no other casualties, officials said. The mine, believed to be a booby trap, exploded after soldiers sent the dog ahead and had groped their way about 700 yards north through the tunnel, Defense Ministry officials said. The army temporarily halted the search, which began Saturday after engineers drilled into the newly discovered tunnel in the Demilitarized Zone. It was the fourth underground passageway found in the DMZ and military officials said they thought there were about 20 more. North Korea has denied digging any tunnels. Ministry officials said they believed Communist North Korea might have installed the booby trap to block the search operation. The tunnel was first detected in December in a remote mountainous region, about 100 miles northeast of Seoul. South Korean officials said Sunday it was believed to have been dug in the 1980s, unlike three other tunnels discovered in 1974, 1975 and 1978. A government statement said the tunnel indicates North Korea's strategy ``has been geared to winning a quick victory'' through a surprise attack. ``North Korea intends to break through our front line on the strength of their superior mobility and fire power, advance speedily behind our forward areas and occupy Seoul quickly,'' it said. The statement said tunnels were an ``integral component of its (North Korea's) military strategy for quick action and quick victory'' and were intended to ``quickly neutralize our major front-line units.'' The two Koreas are separated by the 2.5-mile-wide and 155-mile-long DMZ. The border area on both both sides is heavily fortified by fences, concrete bunkers, mine fields and hundreds of thousands of heavily armed troops. Defense Minister Lee Sang-hoon said Saturday that by analyzing satellite pictures and other information, South Korea knows of at least 26 underground ``axis lines'' beneath the DMZ. He said they are believed to be tunnels. Lee said North Korea bought about 30 excavators with noise-repressing equipment from Sweden after construction noises led to the discovery of the third tunnel in 1978. The Korean peninsula was divided into the Communist North and capitalist South in 1945 after World War II. No peace treaty was signed at the end of the three-year Korean War, only an armistice, and the two nations still are technically at war. They remain bitter enemies and no unauthorized communication is allowed between their citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Kashmir Government Plans Elections in Bid to Halt Uprising
DOC.TEXT: The government of Jammu-Kashmir state offered Sunday to hold elections within six months in a bid to halt a Moslem uprising, and security forces launched new raids on suspected militant hideouts. ``From our side, we are willing to go for a democratic process to decide who should rule the state,'' Gov. Jagmohan said in an interview. ``But the democratic process now depends on those who are terrorizing people,'' he said, referring to the Moslem militants who demand independence from predominantly Hindu India. The militants boycotted November's national parliamentary elections and forced residents in Kashmir _ part of Jammu-Kashmir state _ to stay away from the polls. But Jagmohan, the top administrator of the state, said he had information that various militant groups were considering giving up their arms and adopting the democratic process to power. Jagmohan, a Hindu, uses one name. Jagmohan's statement could not immediately be reconciled with previous statements by militant groups who have rejected everything Indian in their quest for a separate nation. The last state elections, held in 1987, were widely believed to have been rigged by the governing National Conference party and its ally, the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. Gandhi's successor, Prime Minister V.P. Singh, sacked the state government in January, three years before its term was to expire, and brought it under tighter federal control through the governor's rule. At least 163 people have been killed in Kashmir since the latest round of secessionist violence flared up on Jan. 20 following a government crackdown on escalating protests, bombings and attacks on state officials. ``The government is following an iron fist in a velvet glove policy in dealing with the militants,'' said an intelligence officer who is one of the five members of a policy-making team on Kashmir. He spoke on condition of anonymity. On Sunday, paramilitary police and soldiers raided homes of separatist sympathizers and arrested 86 people in Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir, said state officials who cannot be identified under briefing rules. State police sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said at least 150 people had been detained for interrogation since Friday. Srinagar, a city of 1 million people and the focus of the militant movement, remained under curfew for the third straight day. Troops patrolled the streets with orders to shoot curfew violators on sight. The curfew was reimposed in Kashmir early Friday after 49 people were killed by security troops firing on Moslem pro-independence demonstrators. The secession movement has alternately simmered and flared since 1948-49 when the Moslem-dominated state of Jammu-Kashmir, faced with accesion to India or Pakistan, chose India. India and Pakistan were then one year old, having been partitioned along religious lines at the end of the British colonial rule on Aug. 14-15, 1947. Pakistan, which claims Jammu-Kashmir, has twice gone to war with India, in 1948 and 1965. Sixty-four percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslems. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million population. Hindus make up 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Art Thieves Took Ring Believed To Have Belonged to Dracula's Family
DOC.TEXT: A $4 million art theft netted a ring that its owner says belonged to the family of Vlad the Impaler, the Eastern European prince who inspired the vampire legend of Count Dracula, Newsday reported. Two men beat up and handcuffed artist-historian Vlaicu Ionescu, 67, in his apartment in Queens, and took his collection of paintings. They also took documentation on the paintings, leading police to believe the robbery's masterminds knew what they were doing, Newsday reported Sunday. Ionescu, who fled his native Romania more than 20 years ago, said the most valuable work stolen in the August robbery was ``The Barbadori Holy Family with St. John and St. Elizabeth,'' a 1516 painting by Andrea del Sarto worth about $3 million. Also stolen were three signet rings that Ionescu said he acquired in Romania in the 1950s, Newsday said. Ionescu believes the rings belonged to three princes from the 14th and 15th centuries and that one, emblazoned with a raven, belonged to Vlad Dracul of Wallachia, father of Vlad the Impaler. Wallachia is now part of Romania. Vlad the Impaler was known for impaling, boiling alive and mutilating enemies. ``Count Dracula's ring in Queens!'' said the lead investigator, Detective Richard Byrnes. ``That's like saying `We found the true cross up on Forest Hills.''' The police has contacted art experts worldwide, the FBI and Interpol. ``We have leads, but no suspects,'' Byrnes said. Ionescu told Newsday he wasn't insured. The communist government of Romania once confiscated art from him, but he thought his collection would be safe here.

DOC.HEAD: Island Abounds With Ghost Stories
DOC.TEXT: Maybe it's the bleak setting of windswept beaches, brooding moors and gray, weatherbeaten houses. Perhaps it's all the ships lost off the coast, carrying terrified souls into the stormy Atlantic. Whatever the reason, there are ghosts on Nantucket.
