Just ask the people with stories to tell. ``One person I knew thought it had something to do with the moisture,'' says Blue Balliett, who compiled 23 ghost sightings from this tiny island off the coast of Cape Cod and put them into a book. ``I don't know what it is, but there are a lot of ghosts on Nantucket.'' One story tells of a poltergeist residing in a house built in 1808 and once owned, ominously enough, by a man named William Coffin. Coffin, a prominent wig shop owner, died embittered after being accused of stealing $21,000 from the Nantucket bank in 1795. Twenty-one years after the theft, a convict in a New York state prison confessed to the crime, but years of accusations and litigation had left Coffin a broken man. He even sued his distant cousin, Micajah Coffin, over the matter, and he later wrote that he had been victimized by ``chicanery,'' ``phrenzy'' and ``moon-struck madness.'' Peter Benchley, author of the book ``Jaws,'' spent a summer in the Coffin house in the late 1960s. He told Balliett that one afternoon he woke from a nap to see a fire burning in the fireplace. A longhaired old man, dressed in 18th-century clothing, was slowly rocking in a rocking chair in front of the fire. A moment later, the man and the fire had disappeared, and the rocking chair lay still. Out on the island's windswept eastern coast, the normally levelheaded Coast Guard officers keeping watch over the 140-year-old Sankaty lighthouse say a spirit haunts their nearby dormitory. Petty Officer Doug Clark says the ghost scatters pots and pans over the kitchen floor, opens locked doors and spooks the dorm dog, Jessie. ``She'll pop her head up suddenly and look around, and there's nothing there,'' Clark says. ``She gets on edge, and she won't go near where the ghost might be.'' But the hardy Coast Guard men don't put up with too many ghostly gags. ``We'll hear it making loud thumps at night. We just yell, `knock it off,' and it does.'' Sometimes, a spirit reluctant to surrender its home to living residents will get too close for comfort. Joanne Shaw, a Nantucket resident since 1972, recalls when she and her family lived in a 19th-century farmhouse in the center of the island that was haunted by the ghost of a little girl they called Emily. ``She came down the stairs one day, right in front of me,'' Shaw says. ``She was about 10 years, with a cloak covering her face. I watched her for a minute, and then when I started getting scared she disappeared.'' The girl stayed mostly in a third-floor bedroom in the house. She appeared to Shaw and her son, Jimmy, at various times for about two years, and even if she wasn't visible, the floorboards creaked as she passed. Then came the day Shaw was taking a nap and felt the weight of someone getting into the bed next to her. Shaw was frozen with fear for a moment, then jumped out of bed and screamed, ``Get out of here!'' The ghost never returned. The hauntings sometimes jinx real estate deals on the island, though agents are loath to admit it. ``A lot of people won't even look at a house with a reputation for being haunted,'' said agent Gary Winn. ``But we don't have any haunted listings at the moment,'' he added. In June, Balliett's second tome of Nantucket ghost stories will be published, this time with even more accounts. She didn't intend to write another such volume. ``But all these people who saw the first book came out of the woodwork,'' Balliett says. ``On Nantucket, almost everyone has a ghost story to tell.''

DOC.HEAD: America's Response to a New World: Dollars or Discourse?
DOC.TEXT: Congress wants to pump up President Bush's foreign aid budget by as much as $2 billion and shift priorities to reward new democracies from Nicaragua to Czechoslovakia. That move likely will be accompanied by more harsh rhetoric from majority Democrats about the administration's timidity in seizing historic opportunities that the United States has sought for more than four decades in Eastern Europe. ``We are facing a radically different world, but the foreign aid request presented by the administration is changed almost not at all,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., chairman of the House Appropriations foreign aid subcommittee. ``We have a president who's unwilling to invest in things he rhetorically says are important,'' added Rep. Matthew McHugh, D-N.Y. The House Foreign Affairs Committee last week formally asked House budget writers to provide an additional $2 billion for overseas accounts in the year that begins Oct. 1, bringing spending authority to $22.8 billion. That budget category includes everything from bilateral military and economic aid to dozens of friendly countries, to payments to the United Nations and other international organizations, to operations of the State Department and the Voice of America. The administration has proposed $300 million for Eastern Europe in fiscal 1991, but it has offered few details and it remains unclear whether the money represents an increase from current levels or whether it simply continues a three-year program of aide to Poland and Hungary begun last year. The Foreign Affairs Committee estimates the Bush budget would actually fall $291 million short of maintaining current foreign aid programs. So they propose additional money to go for economic aide to encourage the growing of alternative crops in narcotics-producing countries; additional money for aide to Eastern Europe, including Peace Corps development assistance; and increased assistance to Africa, the Eastern Caribbean and Central American democracies such as Nicaragua. Committee Chairman Dante Fascell, D-Fla., wrote that the additional money is ``the essential minimum required to `win the peace' for democracy and free markets around the world.'' Others are calling for creating of a new fund for emerging democracies, outside the normal foreign aid budget, that could meet needs of newly eligible recipients who measure up to certain tests for political, economic and human rights reform. ``We've got a new situation,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. ``This is what we've been working for since the days of Harry Truman. I think we've got to have some new thinking about what we do.'' Because of budget restraints and Bush's no-new-taxes stance, there is no new money to spend on aid or anything else. Any increase in aid must come from cuts in another part of the budget, and most aid proponents are eyeing Pentagon spending. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in testimony on Capitol Hill last week, indicated he sees little likelihood of a substantial increase in the aid budget and suggested instead cutting aid across the board to current recipients to free up some new cash. But despite the unpopularity of aid among U.S. voters, members of Congress are betting that the emergence of democratic governments in formerly totalitarian states will be a politically safe basis on which to send more money overseas. ``Most of our constituents want us to send no money called `foreign aid' overseas,'' said Rep. Jerry Lewis, R-Calif. But he added that ``as we go into a build-down within the military, that's the time to increase our responsibility in foreign affairs.'' Added Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass.: ``We need more resources right now to take advantage of this unprecedented, perhaps temporary, opportunity to win the Cold War. ... We will pay dearly for inaction.'' Aid proponents also believe that if defense spending for next year is cut by as much as $10 billion, with most of the savings devoted to new domestic programs and deficit reduction, public antipathy to a small foreign aid increase will be reduced. The idea of increasing foreign aid also has some powerful support from the Israeli lobby, which is seeking to avoid cuts in its own aid by finding money elsewhere to meet the new demands. As the top aid recipient in the world _ $3 billion of the total $10 billion in U.S. bilateral aid _ Israel stands above the pack when the foreign aid budget gets tight and automatically becomes a target for cuts. In addition to more money, many lawmakers also are calling for a fundamental rewrite of the programs which send military, economic, development and food aid around the world. Policies which have for years been based on countering the communist threat need to be rebuilt on a new rationale, they say. ``We are all still very anti-communist, it's just hard to find a communist to be against,'' said Rep. Mickey Edwards, D-Okla. ``We should create an Albanian theme park so people can come see what communism was all about.'' Added Edwards: ``We are seeing the world remade in America's image. We cannot be timid. We have to move very boldly ... to ensure (the new democracies) do not slip back.'' ``I think we should take a complete new look,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Appropriations foreign aid panel. Leahy said U.S. policy goals have grown poorly defined, and he challenged Bush to show leadership first in setting new goals, then in paying for them.

DOC.HEAD: Lenin Survives Second Day of Demolition Attempts
LaserPhoto BUC2
DOC.TEXT: Crews with jackhammers and blowtorches tried for a second consecutive day Sunday to bring down Bucharest's imposing statue of V.I. Lenin, but by nightfall he was still standing firm. The crews succeeded in eliminating most of the concrete foundation that links the 25-foot, 7-ton bronze statue to its marble base. But engineers on the site said the statue would probably only come down Monday morning, when there would be enough light to do it safely. About 1,000 people watched the workers transfixed, eagerly awaiting the banishment of the statue _ a symbol of the 45 years of Communist rule that ended in December with the ouster of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu by a popular revolt. Ceausescu was executed together with his wife, Elena, on Christmas Day after a summary trial. The ruling Provisional Council of National Unity, which acts as a mini-parliament until national elections scheduled for May 20, voted Friday night to remove the statue from in front of the massive, Stalinist-style state publishing house in the recently renamed Free Press Square. Work began early Saturday, but the work crews were surprised to discover that the statue was implanted deep in its foundation by thick bronze rods. A wrecking ball failed to move the figure. A poster hanging on the motor of one of the cranes being used in the demolition work displayed the Communist slogan ``March onward, Comrades,'' with the addition: ``Don't come back, and take the Securitate with you,'' a reference to Ceausescu's hated secret police. The pink marble base of the statue was covered with blue graffiti reading ``Down with the statue.'' The black statue depicts Lenin holding his cap and the lapel of his overcoat and staring into the distance down a broad avenue toward Bucharest's Arch of Triumph. Authorities said Saturday they had not yet decided what they would do with the statue. About a half-mile to the south in Victory Square, meanwhile, several hundred people demonstrated against the interim government. They were kept well away from the provisional government building, which was ransacked by demonstrators two weeks ago. The military, which did not intervene then, brought out extra troops to surround the building Sunday and blocked off its entrance with 15 armored personnel carriers. The demonstrators chanted ``Down with Communists!'' ``We want true liberty!'' and ``We want free TV!'' Government critics are wary of the Communist past of interim President Ion Iliescu and other former Communists who ran afoul of Ceausescu. Critics also complain about the government's allegedly heavy-handed control of television. Gheorghe Higiu, 45, said that the demonstrators had ``as their first priority supporting the peasants, who form the base of this country.'' Higiu said that the demonstrators were demanding faster privatization of state-owned land, ``which should be distributed free to each peasant according to his ability to work.''

DOC.HEAD: After Voting, Gorbachev Strolls Down Moscow Street _ to His Home?
With AM-Soviet-Elections, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB12
DOC.TEXT: Where does Mikhail S. Gorbachev live? At No. 10 Kosygin Street, a pale-yellow building perched on the highest bank of the Moscow River, with a magnificent view of the city and the Kremlin _ if you believe Sunday's unusual performance, when the Soviet president walked back to this heavily guarded compounded after voting. Moscow's filthy air is fresher in this industry-free neighborhood, which enjoys a luxurious forest surrounding the Stalinesque wedding-cake skyscraper housing Moscow State University. From the street, the yellow edifice appears to be just an unusually fine apartment building with a swingset on the back lawn. Next door is the dull gray building that was the home of the late Alexei Kosygin when he was Soviet premier in the 1960s and 1970s, and for whom the street is named. But from the river below, bay windows and balconies bespeak a rich residence designed to take private advantage of a stupendous site. Neighbors who watched it being built several years ago say the five-floor building extends another five stories into the bedrock of the Lenin Hills. A few hundred yards away, a metro line zips straight to the Kremlin wall. The Pentagon claims the Lenin Hills are laced with civil defense tunnels, and rumors have long circulated in Moscow that Soviet leaders have a private underground train line from the Kremlin to bunkers in this virtual cliff overlooking the capital. The unmistakable ZIL limousines used by a handful of top Soviet leaders only occasionally appear at the blockhouse guarding No. 10 Kosygin Street. ``If Gorbachev lives here, he comes and goes underground,'' said a Westerner who lives in the neighborhood. Gorbachev's true home has always been a source of speculation. The four-ZIL convoy widely assumed to carry the Soviet leader routinely races down Kutuzovsky Prospect and Rublovskoye Shosse, far and away the best-maintained roads in a capital whose streets seem to have more holes than asphalt. Police clear traffic from the middle, so-called ``ZIL lane'' every morning and evening to let the limousines sail by. Locals say that just past Moscow's outer ring road, they turn right down an unmarked road visibly guarded by a lone policeman. At night, the route is brightly lit, standing out in a city short of street lights and generally shrouded in gloom. Gorbachev is widely believed to spend most evenings at a dacha, or country home, in a well-guarded compound down that road. Like many areas on the outskirts of Moscow, foreigners are barred from setting foot in it. During the June 1988 summit, President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, dined with the Gorbachevs at the dacha. Gorbachev's rare stroll down a Moscow street Sunday added new clues, or red herrings, to his trail. The house at 10 Kosygin Street is variously said to be a guest house or one of Gorbachev's residences. After voting at the Institute of Chemical Physics at No. 4 Kosygin Street, he stopped to speak with passers-by and reporters waiting for him, both inside and outside the gates of the heavily wooded grounds of the institute. Then he walked briskly several hundred yards down the boulevard. Hefty security men roughly halted correspondents far from the security gates, where the small crowd surrounding the leader shuffled positions and split up, obscuring the whereabouts of Gorbachev, his wife, Raisa, daughter Irina, her husband, Igor, and their two children. Several drove away in two limousines parked outside, and moments later a third ZIL departed from inside the compound. If Gorbachev had just left his city residence, no one could be sure which long, black vehicle carried him.

DOC.HEAD: Gephardt Sees Nothing Concrete in Bush-Kaifu Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt expressed disappointment Sunday that President Bush's weekend summit with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu produced no specifics on improving the two countries' deteriorating trade relationship. But Gephardt, D-Mo., said Congress will wait until summer to see if mutual pledges by Bush and Kaifu to work toward resolving the disputes produce results before lawmakers move to impose trade sanctions against Japan. ``Nothing has changed,'' Gephardt said of the two-day California summit, which was hastily called by Bush after trade talks between the two countries stalled last month and the annual U.S. trade deficit with Japan fell by only $2.8 billion to $49 billion in 1989. Gephardt, who has been a vocal advocate of strong retaliatory measures against Japan, said he heard no concrete proposals from Bush and Kaifu when they met with reporters Saturday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. ``How many of these press conferences have we seen over the past 10 years?'' Gephardt said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' show. ``What you never hear is a specific goal, an action that both sides are going to take to deal with the problem.'' Kaifu said after the summit he would ``firmly tackle'' the product standards, building codes and other structural impediments that effectively deny U.S. products access to the Japanese market. Bush wished him ``great success.'' But asked if more trade talks between now and June could produce enough movement by the Japanese to avoid U.S. retaliation, Bush said, ``I hope so, but I don't know.'' Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, in a separate interview Sunday, said both leaders left the summit realizing there are serious problems on both sides. Japan, he said, now has top government officials focusing on increasing their country's imports. ``Now at the end of the year, if there aren't some major changes in that, we'll know it was more rhetoric,'' Mosbacher said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program. ``I believe they will.'' Gephardt said Congress will wait until after talks are concluded on Japanese barriers to U.S. supercomputers, satellites and forest products before deciding whether to impose new tariffs on Japanese exports. As part of the 1988 Trade Act, Congress imposed a June 16, 1990, deadline on those talks. A summer deadline also exists on Japanese imports of U.S. semiconductors. ``They want to see what actions the Japanese will actually take as opposed to more promises and then they'll make up their mind as to what should be done next,'' Gephardt said of his colleagues in Congress. But he added that the overall trade relationship between the two countries will not improve significantly until the United States takes a firmer line and establishes targets for reducing the imbalance. ``I would submit to you the Japanese politicians are not able, in present circumstances, to make the changes in their own society that many of them know need to be made unless we are willing to take definitive action to help them do that,'' Gephardt said.

DOC.HEAD: Getting on the `A' List for National Gallery Openings
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 15th graf, bgng: Since then, to CORRECT Odalique to Odalisque
DOC.TEXT: If an engraved summons to a White House state dinner is the ultimate badge of social power, an invitation to a preview breakfast at the National Gallery of Art is the elegant passport to a morning spent contemplating the power of the spirit. About 500 journalists on the gallery's mailing list are accustomed to opening envelopes containing glossy reproductions of a Winslow Homer watercolor, a Frans Hals portrait or the shimmering pastels of an Henri Matisse oil painting. These coveted invitations, surely among the most beautiful ever dropped into a Washington mailbox, are sent to the reporters and art critics who write regularly about the dozen or more major exhibitions that the National Gallery mounts each year. Some recipients consider the invitations themselves to be works of art, worthy of gracing the desks, walls and bulletin boards of newsrooms around the city. No less admired are the buffet breakfasts served in the Refectory, the seventh-floor penthouse suite of the gallery's modernistic East Building, where the culinary theme is taken from the artist of the day. At 9 o'clock Tuesday morning, for instance, about 60 journalists will sit down to a hearty breakfast with a Dutch flavor, a salute to the gallery's March 11 opening of an exhibition of 97 landscape prints and drawings by Rembrandt. The menu will include pannekoeken, or Dutch pancakes, filled with spiced apples and covered with powdered sugar and fresh whipped cream. There will be boiled sweet ham, a platter of aged Gouda, Edam and Memolette cheeses and small raisin buns called krantenbollen, served with butter and blackberry preserves. If he follows the usual format, gallery director J. Carter Brown will introduce the curators over coffee and discuss the new show with his customary wit, good humor and boyish enthusiasm. Then the crowd will adjourn to the Rembrandt gallery for an unhurried preview led by experts on the 17th Dutch master's work. ``I can't imagine a more civilized way to begin the day,'' said one press breakfast regular. ``We offer culture, good food and good conversation,'' says gallery spokeswoman Deborah Ziska. The invitations are the work of Chris Vogel, production manager of the gallery's editorial office, and graphics designer Phyllis Hecht, based on ideas conceived by exhibition curators and public information specialists. Ms. Ziska said it takes six weeks of consultations involving as many as 10 gallery officials _ including Brown _ before the invitations are printed and ready for mailing to a nationwide preview list of 2,500 names, including the local breakfast group. ``We like to do something different that will catch people's eyes,'' said Vogel, who started using artistic images on the gallery's invitations in 1984. That year, for an exhibition of folding screens by Western artists, Vogel used a panoramic black-and-white photograph by Ansel Adams for the cover of an invitation in the shape of a miniature folding screen. Since then, he and Ms. Hecht have collaborated to produce about 100 such invitations, with images ranging from Renoir's eye-popping ``Odalisque'' _ a voluptuous harem beauty _ to an amusing photograph of a weather vane fish waving an American flag, from the Shelburne folk art museum in Vermont. There was no dispute over the choice of an image for invitations to an exhibition of publisher Walter Annenberg's collection of impressionist and post-impressionist masterpieces, which is scheduled to open here May 6. That image will be the expected star of the show, Pablo Picasso's 1905 self-portrait titled ``Au Lapin Agile.'' Annenberg bought the picture in November, after the exhibition opened in Philadelphia last summer, for $40.7 million _ the third most expensive artwork ever sold at auction. Vogel is proud of his invitations but doesn't take his work home. The wall of his house, he said, are reserved for the drawings of his 4-year-old son, Philip.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Terry O'Kelley, who at age 15 promised his dying mother that he would keep his six younger brothers together, said a television movie of his four-year struggle was ``good but sad.'' ``A Son's Promise,'' will air on ABC on Monday. The movie stars Rick Schroder as O'Kelley. ``It made me sad, showing all the things that had happened in my life at one time,'' O'Kelley said Saturday. ``I feel they did a good job.'' After their mother's death, the boys lived together on their grandfather's farm until he died. The boys' story captured national attention, with an outpouring of donations and the creation of a trust fund. In December 1986, a juvenile court judge awarded O'Kelley, now 22, custody of the four oldest brothers: Tommy, now 20; Charles, 19; David, 18; and Jess, 17. The two youngest, Michael and Jason, remain in foster care. O'Kelley is now married and has a son. He lives in a house adjacent to the farm. Three of his brothers live in a house constructed on the farm by volunteers after fire destroyed their mobile home. O'Kelley said he and his brothers benefited from the generosity of ``people that helped us all over the world,'' as well as proceeds from the movie. ``We didn't get rich or anything, but we have the opportunity to get an education, put a down payment on a first home or anything we want,'' he said. ``They got us a good start.''

DOC.TEXT: Sixteen tennis enthusiasts had a formidable _ and expensive _ oppponent over the weekend. Each paid $1,000 for the privilege of playing Ivan Lendl, the No. 1 ranked player in the world. Proceeds went to the Fidelco Guide Dog Foundation of Bloomfield, Conn., which trains dogs for the blind. Letty Landry of West Hartford said she expected to face the Lendl she'd seen on television _ an Iceman whose steely on-court style has chilled opponents. But the Lendl she met Saturday at the Farmington Farms Racquet Club was charming and offered friendly tips, perhaps because playing for charity is recreation for Lendl, not work. ``When you see me on TV, I am in my office,'' he said. ``I am concentrating on my job.'' Saturday's event netted more than $17,000 for Fidelco, said Julie Augeri, spokeswoman for the foundation. About 50 spectators paid $75 apiece to watch the matches. The Czechoslovakian-born tennis champ has four dogs at his house in Greenwich, Conn. Lendl said that he plans to breed German shepherds and will offer some to Fidelco, which trained 37 pairs of dogs and owners last year.

``Pappy'' Neal McCormick has played steel guitar for some of the top names in country music, including Ray Price, Tex Ritter, Gene Autry, Kitty Wells, Ernest Tubb and Johnny Cash. But one performer who stood out among the rest was the 16-year-old boy who came down from Montgomery, Ala., looking for a job with McCormick's band after hearing his Pensacola radio show more than 50 years ago. ``His rhythm weren't no good,'' McCormick drawled during a recent interview at his home near this Florida Panhandle town. But he hired the youngster because ``I thought he was a good singer.'' So did most country fans, and Hank Williams became a legend before his career was cut short. Williams died at 29 on Jan. 1, 1953, from a combination of alcohol and a prescription drug he was taking for back pain. At age 80, McCormick still twangs the steel guitar and his brother, Earl, 83, plays fiddle every Friday and Saturday night. McCormick was picked to headline a special performance Sunday in Pensacola to pay homage to Williams. McCormick disputes the image of Williams as a rowdy drunkard. ``Ol' Hank weren't even a guy like people thought he was,'' McCormick said. ``He was a good-hearted ol' boy as you would ever come around.''

Shirley MacLaine hurt her knee while while dancing the cancan and missed four weekend performances. Dan Bean, president of Entertainment Consultants, said the injury occurred Friday night about 20 minutes before the end of the revue,``Out There Tonight.'' MacLaine finished her performance at the Paramount Theater, but four shows Saturday and Sunday were canceled.

Princess Chulabhorn left Sunday for a 45-day trip to the United States and Canada to meet prominent scientists and observe scientific activities, the Royal Household Bureau said. An official of the bureau said the princess will attend ``The Globe 90 Conference'' on the environment later this month in Vancouver, British Columbia. The princess also will give lectures in Canada. Princess Chulabhorn, 33, has a doctorate in chemistry and is known for her scientific research. Last year, she was appointed by the World Health Organization as one of its ``goodwill ambassadors.'' She is the youngest of the four children of constitutional monarch King Bhumipol and Queen Sirikit.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Praises `New Ortega'
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle said Sunday a ``new Daniel Ortega'' appears committed to democracy in Nicaragua but predicted U.S.-backed contras there will not disband until they feel more secure. Quayle praised the ousted Sandinista leader as being ``very conciliatory'' after Ortega promised on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' show to turn over the reigns of Nicaragua's government on April 25 and to respect its constitution. ``I thought it was on target, and perhaps it appears that we do have a new Daniel Ortega that is truly committed to democracy,'' said Quayle, who was interviewed on the same show immediately after Ortega. He also had praise for former Democratic President Jimmy Carter, who monitored the Nicaraguan election, as being ``helpful in trying to promote democracy.'' Ortega was soundly defeated by President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in elections on Feb. 25. He said Sunday he expects her to establish the country's new government. ``The constitution is the one that orders me to turn over the power to the government that is elected in the elections,'' Ortega said. The ``new administration and the new president will designate the corresponding authorities.'' Asked if he would hand over control of Nicaragua's armed forces and police, Ortega said: ``I don't have an army here, I don't have a police force here.'' Both Chamorro and Ortega have called for the demobilization of the Contra rebels, many of whom remain at camps in Honduras. The Contras have said they would remain intact until after Chamorro's inauguration in April. Quayle said the key to demobilizing the 12,000 Contras is a peaceful transition. While some Contras already have laid down their weapons and returned to Nicaragua, they have done so on a voluntary basis, he said. ``... When democracy is there, and it appears that it's going to be, and when the Contras feel secure, they will demobilize,'' he said. ``That's part of the peace plan.'' The focus, he said, should be on ``putting the principles of democracy to work'' rather than demobilizing the Contras. A group of Nicaraguans is expected to be in Washington Monday to ask the Bush administration for $300 million in aid. Asked what kind of economic assistance the administration is considering, Quayle would say only, ``We will meet the demands of whatever is necessary.'' On other issues, Quayle: _ Said there are ``no negotiations on a quid pro quo basis with Iran'' for the release of U.S. hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslems. He also refused to ``give any little nuance or any little credibility'' to reports the Bush administration is somehow engaged in talks to free the hostages. _ Called the Bush administration's policy on China a ``disappointment'' in that China ``continues to be a holdout of political reform.'' _ Saw no inconsistency in his decision to campaign for Republican Party candidates who believe in the right to have an abortion. Although the Bush administration supports a constitutional amendment banning abortion, Quayle said, ``The REpublican Party is willing to be open on the issue.'' _ Said he wished his approval ratings were higher, but he's given no thought to stepping down as Bush's running mate in 1992 if his standing doesn't improve at the polls. ``You're way down the road _ the president makes decisions like that, not me.''

DOC.HEAD: Chomorro's Coalition Claims Fraud Cost It One Legislative Seat
DOC.TEXT: The coalition that defeated the ruling Sandinistas in last month's general election has charged that vote fraud cost it one seat in the legislature, a newspaper reported Sunday. The newspaper also said that government helicopters fired rockets Saturday at the home of a coalition supporter, injuring two of his children. But the government denied that helicopters caused the blast, and another newspaper said it was caused by a grenade thrown by an unidentified assailant. The charge of election fraud and the report of a helicopter attack appeared in separate articles in La Prensa, the daily newspaper owned by the family of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Since Mrs. Chamorro and her United National Opposition coalition soundly defeated the leftist Sandinistas in the Feb. 25 election, La Prensa has been considered an unofficial voice of the coalition. It has strong ties to the top echelons of the new government, which is to be inaugurated April 25. There has been little serious violence in Nicaragua since the election, but after years of civil war some citizens wonder whether the transition to a new government and the disbanding of the Contra rebels will occur peacefully. Nicaraguan rebels said Sunday they have taken steps toward demobilization. In a statement in Honduras, where the Contras have camps, rebels said they are in contact with UNO leaders and that the speed of the demobilization will depend on guarantees of safety for those returning to Nicaragua. Luis Sanchez, a United National Opposition spokesman, said the coalition will challenge the results of the latest vote count, La Prensa reported. With the results from 4,383 voting stations counted, or 99.8 percent of the total, UNO had 51 seats in the National Assembly and the Sandinista Front had 39. Two tiny parties had one seat each: the leftist Revolutionary Unity Movement and the Social Christian Party. Sanchez accused Sandinista militants of amending the vote counts to deny UNO an additional seat in the single-chamber legislature, La Prensa said. A front-page story in La Prensa said three Soviet-made helicopters from the Sandinista air force fired rockets that injured two children at the home of Trinidad Ubeda, a United National Opposition activist. The report said the attack occurred about noon Saturday in a neighborhood of Jinotega, a mountain town 100 miles northeast of Managua. It said Ubeda's two daughters were treated at a hospital for shrapnel wounds. An official in Managua denied the report. ``They are trying to affect the prestige of the Sandinista People's Army,'' a Defense Ministry spokesman said in an interview with The Associated Press. ``It's illogical that we would commit such a stupid action. A helicopter attack such as the one they describe would have leveled an entire city block, not just a house,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said the incident was under investigation. The staunchly pro-government newspaper El Nuevo Diario quoted an unidentified Interior Ministry source Sunday as saying the children were hurt when an unidentified person tossed a hand grenade into the home. Attempts by the AP to obtain independent confirmation of the details of the reported attack were not immediately successful.

DOC.HEAD: Historic Recall May Attract Republicans to Democratic Primary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for Minocqua-dated story listed on the BC-FYI Planner and the News Advisory.
DOC.TEXT: A state assemblyman whose district has been troubled by a dispute over Indian hunting and fishing rights becomes the first Wisconsin lawmaker to face a recall since 1932. State Rep. James Holperin, of Eagle River, meets Sayner businessman Gene Ahlborn in Tuesday's Democratic recall primary, which was mandated by a petition drive. Brian Sherren, a St. Germain resort owner, is running unopposed in the Republican primary. The general election is set for April 3. Holperin's northern Wisconsin district covers much of Vilas and Oneida counties, two hotbeds for protests against spearfishing by the Lac du Flambeau Chippewa, one of six Chippewa bands in the state and the most active at spearfishing. Non-Indian anglers complain that the Chippewa spearfishing discriminates against them and depletes fish populations. But Wisconsin's Chippewa bands retain the right to spearfish, hunt, cut timber and gather food off reservation under 19th century treaties that ceded northern Wisconsin to the U.S. government. Since a federal court upheld those treaties in 1983, Chippewa spearfishers have been met at northern lakes in the spring by large, rowdy and sometimes violent protests staged by treaty rights opponents, forcing the state to spend millions of dollars to protect tribal members. Frustrations have risen on all sides of the issue in the last year as state efforts to negotiate multimillion-dollar settlements with the tribes were defeated in tribal votes. Opponents of the Indians' rights vented their frustration at 39-year-old Holperin this winter, securing about 6,000 signatures to force a recall. The critics claim Holperin has lost touch with voters on treaty-rights issues. Specifically, they said Holperin supported a failed treaty rights agreement with the Lac du Flambeau Chippewa that a majority of his constituents opposed. No state representative has ever been successfully recalled in Wisconsin. The last recall election was in 1932, when Republican Sen. Otto Mueller of Wausau retained his seat. Observers generally agree Republicans hold the balance of power in Holperin's district. Brian Christianson, Sherren's campaign manager, predicted many GOP members may take advantage of Wisconsin's open primary law and vote in the Democratic primary as they try to vent their frustration over the spearfishing dispute. ``Who they will vote for? I don't know,'' Christianson said. ``In that lies the great mystery of the campaign. If Jim Holperin survives the primary, are those Republicans going to stay with him in the general election?'' Christianson said the treaty rights issue doesn't cut a clear path along party lines. ``You have Republicans who are sympathetic with Holperin and union, blue-collar Democrats against Holperin because they are sportsmen,'' he said. ``I don't think you are going to see a lot of voter apathy in this election.'' Some Republicans want Holperin ousted while others, including Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, feel a recall isn't the proper forum for settling political differences over treaty rights, he said. Sherren, 40, and Ahlborn, 50, a buyer for a family-owned wholesale business, are both making their first runs for the Legislature. Reports filed with the state Elections Board showed that from Jan. 1 through Feb. 19, Holperin's campaign raised $25,705 and spent $17,480. Sherren's report indicated he raised $7,710 and spent $2,946. Ahlborn's campaign spending report was not available, but he said he intended to keep his spending below $10,000.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Could Be Last Major Trial in Iran-Contra Affair
DOC.TEXT: Former national security adviser John Poindexter goes to federal court Monday for what may be the last major trial in the Iran-Contra scandal. Poindexter faces charges that he conspired with former White House aide Oliver North and others inside and outside the Reagan administration to cover up North's secret supply network to the Contras and U.S. involvement in a shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. Reagan gave videotaped testimony for the trial last month, and Poindexter's lawyers are expected to play it back in court. Poindexter is the highest-ranking official in the Reagan White House to go on trial in the affair, the biggest foreign policy debacle of Ronald Reagan's presidency. Accused of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements, Poindexter could face up to 25 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines if convicted. Poindexter's fate will be decided by a U.S. District Court jury of 12 people selected from a pool of District of Columbia residents. Jury selection begins Monday. Iran-Contra prosecutor Dan Webb and defense attorney Richard Beckler will direct opposing teams of trial lawyers in a second-floor courtroom of the U.S. Courthouse at the foot of Capitol Hill. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene will preside at the trial, which could last up to eight weeks. The indictment deals with Poindexter's assertions to Congress in November 1986 that he didn't find out that Hawk missiles had been shipped to Iran in November 1985 until two months after the delivery. The indictment also alleges that Poindexter sent false letters to Congress in 1986 that embraced earlier denials that North was assisting the Contras militarily. Poindexter says his recollection of the November 1985 Hawk shipment was ``very, very fuzzy'' and that while he may have made incorrect statements, he did not lie to Congress. ``My best recollection is ... that I did not remember anything about, or know anything about the Hawks until January '86,'' Poindexter told congressional investigators in immunized testimony in 1987. The CIA-assisted November 1985 shipment of Hawks was authorized retroactively by a presidential finding which Poindexter presented to Reagan for signing after the weapons were delivered. The politically embarrassing finding depicted the transaction with Iran as straight arms-for-hostages trade. Poindexter destroyed the document hours after he told his alleged lies to Congress. Former CIA Director William Casey testified the same day, telling members of the House and Senate intelligence committees the CIA had been told the cargo consisted of spare parts for oil drilling fields in Iran. Casey gave no indication the CIA and National Security Council staff knew that the shipment was arms. In connection with the Contra portion of the indictment, Reagan gave testimony that was favorable to Poindexter. Reagan said ``I am in total agreement'' and ``in complete support'' of letters Poindexter sent to Congress. Poindexter's letters endorsed information national security adviser Robert McFarlane gave Congress in 1985 denying that North was raising money or providing military advice to the Nicaraguan rebels. McFarlane subsequently pleaded guilty to crimes in connection with the information he had provided in letters to Congress. Reagan said he hadn't known McFarlane had pleaded guilty in connection with the letters and said he didn't know the Tower commission which he appointed had concluded North was assisting the Contras militarily. In his videotaped testimony, the former president said he didn't think Poindexter had made any false statements in the Iran-Contra affair. In addition, Reagan suggested it might have been all right in November 1986 as the Iran-Contra affair was unfolding to destroy documents and withhold information from Congress. That body, explained Reagan, habitually leaked sensitive information that in this instance might have jeopardized the lives of U.S. hostages held in Lebanon. Part of the conspiracy charge accuses Poindexter of working with North to destroy classified documents and records of the National Security Council. North was convicted by a jury last May of three felonies in the Iran-Contra scandal, sentenced to 1,200 hours of community service, fined $150,000 and given two years' probation. One of the crimes for which North was convicted _ aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress _ involved the November 1985 shipment of Hawks for which Poindexter is now charged. North is appealing the convictions and the fine while performing the community service in an anti-drug program. Richard Secord and Albert Hakim, businessmen who assisted North in supplying the Contras and ship arms to Iran, pleaded guilty to crimes in the Iran-Contra affair and were placed on probation. Businessmen Carl Channell and Richard Miller, who raised private donations for the Contras, pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud the government of taxes and were placed on probation. The Bush administration stepped in and blocked the use of some classified material in the case of Joseph Fernandez, the former CIA station chief in Costa Rica. As a result of the action by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, the judge in the case dismissed charges that Fernandez lied about his assistance to North's Contra resupply network. Iran-Contra prosecutors are appealing. Thomas Clines, a former CIA agent who assisted North in locating sources of arms and shipping them to the Contras, is under indictment for alleged tax violations in the scandal and is scheduled to appear in federal court in Baltimore later this month.

DOC.HEAD: In Gorbachev Household, Raisa Runs the Party
With AM-Soviet-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev may run the Soviet Union, but at home, it's his wife, Raisa, who's in charge of the family's politics, the Soviet leader joked Sunday. Speaking to Soviet TV at the polling station where he voted for legislators to the Russian republic, Gorbachev said it was difficult to choose among the many candidates. ``I should say that there was a meeting of our party organization at home,'' he said. ``At our house it's Raisa Maximovna who's the secretary of the party organization.'' To the chuckles of reporters and others in Gorbachev's entourage, Raisa countered: ``Probably they'll remove me soon.'' Gorbachev, with a grin, said the family managed to reach a decision and ``come to the polls with a united platform _ if no one has changed his mind.'' Raisa, with a laugh, said Gorbachev was after her downfall. ``(He) wants to have me removed. Get it? That's the main thing,'' she said. The polling station scene, carried on the nightly news, was a rare light moment in days of political tension for Gorbachev. His proposal for a Soviet presidency with vastly expanded powers comes before the Soviet Congress soon. Raisa Gorbachev is seen by many Soviets as a rather domineering woman who is unwilling to take the retiring role common to wives of past Soviet leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov Clinches Slim Victory In Spanish Chess Tourney
DOC.TEXT: World chess champion Gari Kasparov of the Soviet Union won his final match, edging out his countryman, Boris Gelfand, in the eighth City of Linares tournament. Kasparov beat Miguel Illescas of Spain in 61 moves late Saturday to end the 11-round tournament with 8 points, just 0.5 ahead of Gelfand, 21, who strengthened his reputation as a contender for Kasparov's world crown. Kasparov was awarded 875,000 pesetas ($8,100) and an all-terrain vehicle for winning the tournament, which pitted 12 of the world's top players against one another. In his final match, 14th-ranked Gelfand drew with countryman Vasily Ivanchuk, who finished fourth with 6.5 points. Valeri Salov was third, with 7 points, after drawing with fellow Soviet Alexander Beljavsky, who ended up eighth with 5 points. Briton Nigel Short was fifth, with 6 points, followed by U.S. player Boris Gulko and Soviet Artur Yusupov, with 5.5. Illescas finished ninth with 4 points, the same as former world champion Boris Spassky and Lajos Portisch of Hungary. Yugoslavia's Ljubomir Ljubojevic had three points and finished 12th. In other matches Saturday: Spassky drew with Gulko. Portisch drew with Yusupov. Ljubojevic drew with Short.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Singh Resigns as Party Chief
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh resigned as president of his Janata Dal party, in keeping with earlier promises to step aside to avoid holding two offices, a party spokesman said Sunday. Singh resigned late Saturday at a party meeting called to discuss alleged vote fraud by a party leader, spokesman Jaipal Reddy said. The party leader, Om Prakash Chauthala, was also accused of inciting violence during a by-election last month. In a measure seen as a face-saving move in the absence of Chauthala's resignation, the Press Trust of India said the party Sunday recommended the Election Commission repeat balloting in Meham, Harayana state, where Chauthala was a candidate. Reddy denied the prime minister's decision was linked to the election dispute. He said Singh's decision was in accordance with his repeated declarations he would not hold two offices to avoid conflict of interest. Singh became prime minister in December, promising to uphold democracy and respect public institutions, which he said his predecessor Rajiv Gandhi had ignored. In the past, government leaders have used benefits for party business, opening them to charges of misuse of public office. A New Delhi English language newspaper, Indian Express, said Singh's decision would have ``implications for many others in the Janata Dal'' who hold both a party post and public office. Reddy said Singh was asked to continue as party leader until alternative arrangements are made. Chauthala, the eldest son of Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal, was appointed to the post of chief minister but was required under Indian law to seek the voters' mandate to ratify his position. News reports said that in the Feb. 27 by-election in Meham, 60 miles northwest of New Delhi, violence broke out when Chauthala's supporters tried to stuff ballot boxes and intimidate voters. A second vote Feb. 28 also was marred by rigging and violence that left at least 13 people dead, and Chauthala was blamed. The by-election was held along with balloting for eight state legislatures and lawmakers in a federally controlled territory. Gandhi's Congress Party suffered heavy losses in the elections, while Singh's Janata Dal and the right-wing Hindu fundamentalist Indian People's Party made strong gains.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Soviet Split Would be Worse than Cultural Revolution
With AM-Soviet-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Sunday that the breakup of the Soviet Union could be more devastating to his country than the ruinous Cultural Revolution that wracked China for 10 years. The Soviet leader spoke to reporters after voting in elections for the Russian republic. Asked if he could put up with the Baltic republics declaring independence, Gorbachev said that trying to disentangle the nationalities of the Soviet Union after decades of living together would lead to trouble comparable to the upheaval in China that started in 1966. ``Just think of more than 60 million people living outside their national lands,'' Gorbachev said, referring to the more than 100 nationalities in the Soviet Union. ``Just imagine these millions of people on the move,'' he said. ``This will throw the country back. This will bring trouble to people who have lived in some place for decades, which has become their second motherland.'' ``Over these decades, the interests of the republics and the people have become so entangled that if we now started to divide the entire country, this would lead to trouble,'' he said. ``It would be worse than the Cultural Revolution in China. This simply cannot be allowed to happen.'' Mao Tse-tung's attempt to revive revolutionary fervor in China sparked a violent struggle for power that led to the closing of universities for four years, destruction of antiquities, and a devastating setback in the country's economic development. An estimated 1 million people died. Ethnic tension and demands for independence from small republics increasingly threaten Soviet unity. The latest unrest was reported in the city of Parkent in the Central Asian republic of Uzbekistan. Official reports said at least one soldier was killed Saturday in unrest in the city. It was not clear what sparked the violence, but Uzbekistan has been the scene of ethnic unrest in the past. The Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania, and Estonia have been campaigning to regain the independence they had before being annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Some Lithuanians are calling for their newly elected parliament to take office and vote on independence this week, before Gorbachev can win approval for a presidency with vastly expanded powers. Separatists fear the more powerful position could be used against them. Some have said it could lead to restoration of a dictatorship, because it would allow the president to suspend republics' parliaments and send in troops without the approval of local authorities. Gorbachev promised Sunday that a revision of his proposal, due to be published this week, would ease these fears. ``There will be no possibility of repeating what happened in the years of the command-administrative system,'' he said, referring to the regimes of his predecessors. If Gorbachev's proposals are approved by national legislators, the first president to hold the wider powers _ expected to be Gorbachev _ would be elected by parliament. Subsequent leaders would be chosen in a national vote. Gorbachev said Sunday that he would not refuse nomination to the post. He also gave some support to nationalists in the Soviet Union, saying, ``I do not think that the striving for national independence, self-reliance and sovereignty is ambitious.'' But he said it should be achieved through a reformation of the Soviet structure as a federation. At a meeting Sunday of the Moscow Tribune, a progressive citizen's group, member Anatoly Akhutin warned that the presidency proposal ``is a way of introducing a general state of emergency.'' Another member, Vladimir Bibler, called for signatures on a resolution terming the proposal anti-democratic, unless the nation first establishes a promised multiparty system, a new constitution, a stronger parliament, and direct popular election of the president. Gorbachev has supported all of these, yet none has been implemented.

DOC.HEAD: Israel's Leaders: No Response To U.S. Plan for Talks
DOC.TEXT: Israel's four top leaders on Sunday debated U.S. proposals for opening Middle East peace talks, but they failed to bridge differences blocking a response to the plan. Vice Premier Shimon Peres, leader of the center-left Labor Party, insisted that the Cabinet vote on the compromises by Wednesday, but officials in Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc objected. ``In matters pertaining to Israeli survival ... we have to make decisions by ourselves without a gun to our temple,'' said Transport Minister Moshe Katzav, a Shamir ally. Deputy Premier David Levy, Likud's leading opponent of the compromises, threatened to resign if the Cabinet agrees to the U.S. plan. Peres said shortly before Sunday's meeting of the ``forum of four'' _ two leaders from each of the main parties _ that he ould hold Likud to a Wednesday deadline for putting the U.S. proposals to a vote by the decision-making Inner Cabinet. ``There is no need to wait, the picture is clear,'' he said. Labor leaders have threatened to quit the governing coalition if no decision is made by Wednesday. But Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, another Labor leader, said he could wait until next week for the 12-member Inner Cabinet to make its decision. The ``forum of four,'' which includes Shamir and Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Likud and Peres and Rabin of Labor, met for 45 minutes Sunday. Rabin later told Israel army radio that they failed to decide on the proposals by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III because Likud's ministers remained divided. Baker has been trying to bring together Israelis and Palestinians for preliminary talks in Cairo on Israel's plan for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The elections would be a step toward limited autonomy for the territories, which Israel has occupied since 1967. Baker reportedly wants to start the talks April 2, but Likud has resisted his proposals to include residents of Arab east Jerusalem and two Palestinians who were deported by Israel among the Palestinian negotiators. Those proposals were intended to meet PLO demands to include outside Palestinians in the talks but still meet Israel's demand to only talk to residents of the territories. Likud officials fear the compromises would bring members of the Palestine Liberation Organization into peace talks, and would raise questions about Israel's control of Jerusalem. Israel refuses to talk to the PLO, which it views as a terrorist group. According to Israeli news reports, Baker has suggested a new formula of accepting in principle any negotiator who is a registered resident of the territories, which could include deportees or Palestinians with ties to east Jerusalem. Individual names could be discussed later. Deputy Premier Levy remained staunchly opposed to the plan Sunday. ``The formula in essence includes all the dangerous elements that Likud opposes,'' he said. Shamir spokesman Avi Pazner denied earlier reports that the premier favored Baker's ideas. ``The prime minister hasn't told anyone if he supports the proposals or not. He hasn't had his say,'' Pazner said.

DOC.HEAD: Slavic Republics Head to Polls in Key Local Balloting
LaserPhotos MOSB2,3,4,7
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th pvs, `No results...' to UPDATE with reports from runoffs in Lithuania. Pick up 5th pvs, `Officials reported...' ADDS 3 grafs with details.
DOC.TEXT: Millions of Soviets from the Polish border to the Bering Strait voted Sunday in what President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said was a struggle between reform and bureaucracy for the country's Slavic heartland. ``I think it is a battle,'' Gorbachev told reporters after voting in the Lenin Hills area of Moscow, ``but I am convinced that perestroika will win.'' Almost 150 million voters were registered to choose among more than 11,000 candidates for 1,800 seats in the legislatures of the Russian, Ukrainian and Byelorussian republics. Thousands of seats in local governing councils also were being contested. No results were expected until Tuesday in the three republics, which comprise the vast majority of the country's territory and hold more than two-thirds of the Soviet Union's 290 million people. In the Baltic republic of Lithuania, meanwhile, pro-independence activists said results in runoff elections Sunday assured them of the quorum they need to covene the republic's parliament, where activists are expected to push for creating a mechanism to secede from the Soviet Union. Officials reported a strong turnout in the Far East region and the Ukraine, where more than half of registered voters had been to polling stations before noon. Polls were open from 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. There was increased political tension over Gorbachev's reforms in the weeks leading to the elections. Gorbachev has pressed the Communist Party to relinquish its monopoly on power and pushed for a new, more powerful presidency. Hundreds of thousands of Soviets have turned out for pro-democracy rallies. In the Slavic republics, reforms _ where they have managed to get started _ have proceeded more slowly and quietly than in other areas. There have been neither the concerted drives of the Baltic republics nor the violence of the Caucasus and Central Asia. Gorbachev and Soviet citizens said the local party and government officials seeking election were among national leaders most opposed to reforms. ``Our elections involve a new type of people, people who have been given new impetus from perestroika,'' a relaxed, confident Gorbachev said. ``The essence of it is that it is a people's referendum on perestroika.'' The Soviet leader, who was accompanied to the polls by his wife Raisa, daughter, son-in-law and two grandchildren, urged Soviets to ``come forward and take greater responsibility for themselves.'' Responding to reporters' questions as he left the polling station at the Institute of Chemical Physics, the Soviet leader said it was not particularly important whether the victors were Communist Party members. The 20-million member party is trying to get much closer to the people, ``and so the question of proportions is not crucial,'' he said. ``It is important that people are there who support perestroika and are prepared to move this process ahead. Communist or non-party members, all will be good enough,'' he said. Hundreds of longtime party and government officials were candidates. In Russia alone, the ballot contained 25 heads of regional Communist Party organizations and 36 chairmen or deputy chairmen of autonomous regions within the giant republic. In the days before the balloting, official newspapers were full of stories of campaign tricks and pork-barrel politics. Officials sought to avoid the kind of embarrassing defeats they suffered last year in balloting for the national Congress of People's Deputies. Voters in the Ukraine selected a 450-member Supreme Soviet legislature, Byelorussia chose a 310-member legislature and Russia elected a 1,068-member congress that will choose a legislature and leadership from among its members. Reformist Communist leader Boris Yeltsin, who voted at a children's center in central Moscow, told reporters the turnout was likely to be ``significantly lower'' than balloting for the national Congress last March. In that race, Soviets were given their first choice of candidates in more than 70 years. Yeltsin was a candidate for a district in his Ural Mountains home of Sverdlovsk. As the Communist maverick appeared, several people waiting for him whispered among themselves, ``Here comes the president of Russia,'' a reference to his candidacy for the new post of the presidency of the republic, to be elected by legislators. Voters on the Kamchatka Peninsula of the Soviet Far East, who were among the first to go to the polls, had as many as 12 candidates to choose from for each seat. In Leningrad, 280 candidates were seeking 34 seats. About 3,000 candidates in the Ukraine were vying for 450 seats in the republic's Supreme Soviet, and in Byelorussia there was an average of five candidates for each seat, the Tass news agency said. Vitaly Boiko, chairman of the Ukrainian election commission, said from Kiev that as of 6 p.m. more than 80 percent of the 37 million voters had gone to the polls. ``In my opinion, it's explained by the fact that people want perestroika to go faster, they want the formation of the new organs of Soviet power to be completed,'' he said. Sergei Odarych, an election official for the informal Ukrainian political group Rukh, reported minor irregularities but said the problems were easily straightened out. Ivan Likhach, official of Byelorussian election commission, said from Minsk that about half the eligible voters had been to the polls by noon, and turnout was running ahead of last March's elections. ``Activism is higher this year,'' he said. Ukrainian Communist Party chief Vladimir A. Ivashko, a member of the national party Politburo, faced 11 challengers. Official reports said 86 percent of candidates in the Russian elections and 80 percent in the Ukraine were members of the Communist Party. Newspapers have been filled with reports of campaign tricks. The Workers' Tribune newspaper said workers in one Moscow district were paving over snow to meet the campaign promise of Mayor Valery T. Saikin and appease voters who swore they wouldn't vote unless parking lots were built. Saikin, defeated a year ago in national elections, was a candidate for re-election to the 498-member Moscow city council. Balloting in the Slavic republics followed an election in the Baltic republic of Lithuania swept by candidates endorsed by the pro-independence Sajudis movement, and several other republics. Voters in 28 Lithuanian districts cast ballots in runoff elections Sunday. Runoffs in the remaining 17 districts not settled in the Feb. 24 election will be held later in the week, Tass said. On Sunday, at least nine deputies to the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet were elected, eight of them supported by the pro-independence movement Sajudis, said Longinas Vasiliauskas, a Sajudis spokesman. Two-thirds of the 140-member parliament must have been elected before a session can be called. Observers have speculated that Sajudis wants a quick parliament session so Lithuania can vote to secede from the Soviet Union before Gorbachev gains his expected broad new powers, which include the right to suspend republic parliaments and send in troops. The Soviet Congress meets next Monday to consider Gorbachev's proposal. Vasiliauskas said the Lithuanian parliament would not vote to leave the Soviet Union immediately but wants to create the mechanism for secession because ``We don't know what Gorbachev will do after he's elected president.''

DOC.HEAD: New Storm Moving Ashore On West Coast
DOC.TEXT: Stormy weather dominated the West Coast on Sunday as a cold front moved ashore with rain and snow, and snow also was scattered around the Great Lakes. Snow advisories were issued Sunday for the mountains of northern California, southern Oregon and western Nevada, and a winter storm watch was in effect through Monday for east-central and northeastern Nevada. During the day Sunday, mostly rain fell over northern California and western Oregon, and a few showers also developed over western Washington state and southern California. The heaviest rain for the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST was 0.82 of an inch at Crescent City, Calif., on the state's northern coast Farther inland, a vigorous upper-level weather system moved across Colorado during the night, producing snow in the northern and central mountains. The Arapaho Basin and Winter Park ski areas got up to 8 inches of snow, and Vail got 7 inches. Light snow fell over parts of Wisconsin and Minnesota, and was scattered around the lower Great Lakes. Parts of Wisconsin got 2 inches of snow during the night. Light snow also fell over Maine and New Hampshire. Showers and thunderstorms moved across southern Florida during the night and were over the Florida Keys by afternoon. Afternoon temperatures were still below freezing in the upper Mississippi Valley, the Great Lakes region and the Northeast, and northern Michigan had subzero lows during the night. Temperatures warmed into the 60s and 70s from Texas to Florida, and over southern California and southern Arizona. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 6 below zero at Pellston, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Hotels Scramble to Replace Striking Workers
DOC.TEXT: Strike-bound hotels are flying in support staff and advertising for replacement workers as they struggle to keep some of Hawaii's biggest hotels open for tourists. The 7,500 members of the Local 5 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union went on strike Saturday in a contract dispute against 11 major hotels and resorts in Hawaii. The hotels remained open Sunday but many closed their restaurants and snack shops and curtailed services after the strike began. The 11 hotels account for one of every five hotel rooms in Hawaii and two of every five hotel rooms in Waikiki, the state's main tourist destination. Federal mediator Frank Schoeppel said no new contract talks will be scheduled for at least seven days. Tony Rudledge, union president, promised to pressure hotel management until the union's demands are met. ``We may be having some massive sit-ins that the employers may not like and we may get arrested for trespassing,'' said Rutledge. ``You don't get too far walking in a (picket) circle.'' Hilton Hotels, owner of Hilton Hawaiian Village, the largest resort in Hawaii with 2,532 rooms, brought in about 50 managers from the mainland, said spokewoman Jeanne Park. The hotel also was hiring temporary replacements. Park said the resort almost had the 700 to 750 people it needed for the day shift Saturday. The hardest spots to fill, she said, were maids and cooks. The Hyatt Regency Waikiki started shifting managers from its hotels on other Hawaiian islands Thursday, said Joanna Robles, director of public relations who also was supervising a housecleaning crew. The Hyatt wasn't signing temporary workers, she said. Sheraton Hotels started a radio advertising campaign Saturday to recruit as many as 2,000 temporary workers, said spokeswoman Maggie Wunsch. Neither side expected a quick resolution to the dispute, which centers on wages and benefits, as well as union demands for a 5 percent room surcharge that would be divided among all workers who don't get tips and a 15 percent surcharge on all food and beverage purchases. Bill Crawford, executive director of the Council of Hawaii Hotels, which represents employers, said the union rejected a four-year deal that called for annual wage increases of 5 percent plus hikes in benefits that boosted the total package to around 7 percent a year. Rodriguez said the union calculated the management proposal at around 4 percent, which he said was lower than the 5 percent package offered Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Campaign Stunt Foiled by Weather
With AM-Germany-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party leader Gregor Gysi, trying to boost his party's election standings with a sky-diving stunt, suffered an early setback Sunday when high winds forced him to call off his parachute jump. Communist Premier Hans Modrow, meanwhile, was headed to Moscow for talks with a worried Kremlin about trade and security after the March 18 elections, which are expected to sweep the Communists out of power and speed unification with West Germany. The Communists are running a distant third in the campaign for parliamentary seats in East Germany's first competitive election in its 40-year history. Gysi addressed a rally in East Berlin's Hellersdorf region, then suited up for his planned sky-diving stunt, after which he was to have landed back at the rally site. But the jump was canceled because of gale-force winds that swept through Berlin over the weekend. Gysi, 41, is attempting to boost the Communist image, which has been badly tarnished by past corruption and abuses of power. He drew a capacity crowd at East Berlin's House of Parties for a campaign appearance before the scheduled jump. He promised that Communist lawmakers would fight to ensure that ``40 years of social accomplishments'' are not wiped out by a hasty merger with West Germany. As officials from both sides negotiate how to mesh the two German economies and societies after four decades of division, East Germans have become fearful of unemployment, huge rent increases and other consequences of capitalism. East Germany's ADN news agency said Modrow was to meet with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Monday to discuss reunification. ADN, citing unidentified sources in Moscow, suggested that the Soviet leadership remains concerned about how German unification would influence the Soviet economy and security. East Germany has traditionally been the Soviets' most important trading partner and defense ally. The Soviets have indicated they will allow reunification, but Gorbachev has said the new nation should be militarily neutral. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl says a united Germany should be part of the NATO alliance. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher on Sunday reiterated his view that West Germany should make clear its intent to respect Poland's current western border after reunification. In an interview with the ZDF television network, Genscher further distanced himself from Kohl, who has refused to provide Poland a guarantee. Genscher's Free Democratic Party is a junior partner in the government with Kohl's Christian Democratic Union. Poland has asked that the two Germanys begin work on a treaty to recognize the Oder and Neisse rivers as the permanent border between Germany and Poland. It is afraid a reunited Germany might press claims to prewar territories that now make up about a third of Poland. Kohl, apparently fearing the loss of arch-conservative voters in December elections, has refused to provide a guarantee, saying it would be up to a reunited Germany to decide. But he said Friday that he favors a reunited Germany signing a treaty to fix the border if Poland also agrees to waive all claims to war reparations and guarantees the rights of ethnic Germans. Poland, which already waived such reparations in 1953, has rejected Kohl's new suggestions. In the ZDF interview, Genscher issued a veiled warning to Kohl that he should not bring into question issues that have already been resolved. The border question was also expected to be a central topic during the talks between Modrow and Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Small College Merges With Japanese University
DOC.TEXT: For its 100th birthday, a small private college in northwest Iowa is getting a new name, millions of dollars and an affiliation with a Japanese university. Westmar College's board of trustees highlighted the school's centennial Saturday by voting to become a branch of Teikyo University of Japan. ``Our community just got bigger and the world just got smaller,'' Westmar President Arthur Richardson told a cheering crowd of students, faculty and residents after the board vote. Richardson refused to disclose the vote by the 37-member board but said more than two-thirds agreed to rename the school Teikyo Westmar University. The agreement gives Teikyo its third branch university in the United States. Teikyo has reached agreements with Regis College to buy its Loretto Heights campus in Denver and with Salem College in Salem, W. Va. The Tokyo-based Teikyo has nine campuses elsewhere in Japan as well as branches in England and Holland. Richardson said the 566-student college had been seeking an international agreement since the mid-1980s when the school was in financial trouble and enrollment dipped to 417. Teikyo Westmar University will receive $4 million from Teikyo to refurbish dormitories and classroom buildings, increase salaries, hire additional faculty and to enroll as many as 400 Japanese students by the fall of 1991. As many as 200 Japanese are expected to arrive this spring in Le Mars, 20 miles northeast of Sioux City. Richardson said the Westmar College board would be dissolved and the new board would have at least seven members, the majority Americans. An acting board chairman will be Takashi Yamanaka, who is also chairman of the executive committee at Teikyo Loretto Heights University. Richardson was criticized by some for waiting until last month to inform faculty and trustees about the proposal he began negotiating last November. ``They have called it a marriage. But in my judgment the engagement period was way too short. We didn't have a chance to get acquainted,'' said Robert Rydell of Des Moines, chairman of the board of trustees until he and three other members resigned to protest Richardson's actions. ``It did kind of happen all of a sudden,'' Richardson said. ``But you can't announce a gift you don't have.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Greeted With Cheers in Zimbabwe
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela arrived in Zimbabwe Sunday to the cheers of thousands of well-wishers and an embrace from President Robert Mugabe, a former black guerrilla fighter who like Mandela spent years in jail. Mugabe, who long agitated for Mandela's release from South African prisons, welcomed the South African black leader on the tarmac at Harare airport as thousands cheered to the throb of tribal drums. ``You're not a stranger!'' Mugabe declared. ``You've come home where the 10 million people stand solidly behind the people of South Africa in the unrelenting struggle.'' Children in feather headdresses chanted, ``We're going to Pretoria to fight!'' Mandela said his African National Congress was anxious for talks with the Pretoria government. ``We are trying to convince the white minority that it is madness that we should be killing one another when we can sit down, talk and settle our problems,'' he said. ``The day they (the South African government) decide to settle with the acknowledged leaders of the country and the day they commit themselves to a democratic and non-racial South Africa they will be accepted in the region, in Africa and other parts of the world with open arms,'' Mandela said. Zimbabwe, a former British colony that won independence after a bloody guerrilla war, is the second stop on Mandela's four-nation tour. Mandela, now vice president of the ANC, will leave for Mozambique in three days and later travel to Sweden to visit ailing ANC President Oliver Tambo. Mandela, 71, was freed Feb. 11 after more than 27 years in prison for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white government. In Zimbabwe, he will witness firsthand how white-governed Rhodesia was transformed into black-ruled Zimbabwe. Aides to the ANC leader say he views Zimbabwe as a possible model for a future South Africa. Mugabe himself spent 10 years in detention under the regime of Rhodesian Prime Minister Ian D. Smith before he led the seven-year war that ended with independence in 1980. On Sunday, giant portraits of Mandela festooned lampposts and trees on the road to the airport. One placard displayed at the airport read, ``Mandela _ destroyer of the apartheid monster.'' Apartheid is the South African system of racial segregation under which the 28-million black majority has no vote. President F.W. de Klerk, who says he wants to bring blacks into the political system, has lifted bans on opposition groups and initiated other reforms, Speaking to thousands of Mugabe loyalists at a soccer stadium, Mandela said the key to South Africa's future lies not only in the black majority gaining the vote, but also in the unity of rival black factions. He pointed to the example of Zimbabwe, where Mugabe formally merged his political forces last year with those of his chief rival, Joshua Nkomo. Since coming to power, Mugabe has pursued a policy of reconciliation between whites and blacks, rival tribes and opposition political movements. Whites have held Cabinet posts. Sunday's rally was to launch Mugabe's governing Zimbabwe African National Union (Patriotic Front) party's campaign for parliamentary and presidential elections at the end of this month.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: You need two things to be a turkey calling champion, says Walter Parrott. A good ear and an understanding wife. ``You have to have a good rhythm, an ear for rhythm, tones, sounds,'' said the defending champion at the National Wild Turkey Federation meeting. And ``you have to have a wife that'll listen to it,'' Parrott said. But Parrott, 34, of Doe Run, Mo., was out-clucked Saturday by Matt Morrett who strutted off with the national championship. The 19-year-old Morrett from Harrisburg, Pa., first competed at age 6. He's been gobbling up awards ever since. Contestants had to give the tree call of a hen turkey, the assembly call of an old hen, the yelp of a hen in springtime, the whistle and call of a lost turkey, the cutting of an excited hen, and the cluck and purr of a hen. There was a little actor in the callers as they crouched and rose, hands cupped around their mouths, imitating the sounds of a turkey in spring or an old hen calling an assembly of birds. Judges concentrated on the sound from behind a white curtain and their backs to the caller.

Two sisters separated in Cambodia were reunited 16 years later when one of the women happened to go into a Providence restaurant where the other one worked. Sideth Prak, 30, was running the kitchen at the Phnom Penh restaurant two weeks ago when she noticed one of the customers, Bhopa Ros. The woman's tiny figure and solemn expression were much like her own. She listened to the woman's voice and went running back to the kitchen. ``I think that's my sister out there,'' she told her husband. Bhopa, then 8, had become separated from her family when the Communist Khmer Rouge arrived in Phnom Penh in 1975. Sideth was visiting an uncle in another province and was trapped there when the Khmer Rouge seized power. Years later, they both made their way to the United States _ Bhopa settled in Malden, Mass., and Sideth in Rhode Island. While in Providence two weeks ago, a Cambodian friend suggested they eat at the Phnom Penh restaurant where the reunion took place. Two days later, Bhopa moved to Cranston to join her sister. She celebrated her 23rd birthday with her family Friday. ``I feel so great,'' she said. ``When I met my sister, I quit my job. Even if I work here washing dishes ... I don't care. I don't want to miss any more.''
